PREFACE
   This code of the City of Momence, as supplemented, contains ordinances up to
and including ordinance 893, passed May 5, 2025. Ordinances of the City adopted
after said ordinance supersede the provisions of this code to the extent that
they are in conflict or inconsistent therewith. Consult the City office in
order to ascertain whether any particular provision of the code has been
amended, superseded or repealed.
American Legal Publishing
Cincinnati, Ohio

Listed ordinances have been passed, but they have not been incorporated into
the code and they may not show the original ordinances in their entirety.
Please contact the office of the clerk if there are any questions concerning
the ordinances listed.
ORDINANCE NO. 881
AN ORDINANCE AMENDING AN ORDINANCE REGULATING THE GENERAL LICENSING PROVISIONS
WHEREAS, the City Council of the City of Momence, Illinois, desires to ensure
the safety and well being of its citizens, inhabitants, and all other persons
within the City limits of
the City of Momence, Illinois; and
WHEREAS, the City Council of the City of Momence, Illinois, has considered that
City Code created in1978 concerning general licensing provisions be updated;
and
                
WHEREAS, the City Council of the City of Momence, Illinois wishes to amend the
City Code, specifically under a portion of the Code known as Title 3, Chapter
1, Sections 1 through 12.
 
NOW, THEREFORE, be it ordained by the City Council of the City of Momence,
Illinois as follows:
 
SECTION 1: That Title 3, Chapter 1, Sections 1 through 12, of the City Code of
the City of Momence, Illinois is hereby repealed.
 
SECTION 2: That there is hereby added to the City Code of the City of Momence,
Illinois the following Sections 1 through 15, under and in substitution for
Title 3, Chapter 1, Sections 1 through 12, of the City Code of the City of
Momence, Illinois hereinabove repealed.
 
 
 
 
 
TITLE 3
BUSINESS REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL LICENSING PROVISIONS
3-1-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
(A)   All businesses having a physical location in the city shall be licensed
by the city, unless exempt from municipal licensing by state statutes, by
January 1st of each year. It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct,
engage in, maintain, operate, carry on, or manage a business, occupation,
activity, or offer for use by the public, equipment, devices or machines, for
which a license is required, without a license first having been procured for
such business or occupation.
(B)    All businesses having a physical location outside of City limits, at the
time of doing business within City limits, unless exempt from municipal
licensing by state statutes, shall be required to obtain a license, which shall
be in effect for twelve (12) months, and pay a twenty five dollar ($25.00) fee
before being issued a permit.
3-1-2: APPLICATION PROCEDURE:
(A)    Application for all licenses and permits required by City Code shall be
made in person at City Hall to the City Collector in the absence of provisions
to the contrary.
(B)    Each application shall state the name of the applicant, the license
desired, the location to be used, if any, the time covered, and the fee to be
paid. Each application shall contain such additional information as may be
needed for the proper guidance of City officials in the issuing of the license
for which applied.
(C)    All businesses shall show proof of insurance before a license is
issued. 
3-1-3: LICENSE EXEMPTIONS:
(A)    Not for profit organizations are required to have a license, but are
exempt from all fees.
(B)    Tax exempt certificate required at time of application.
3-1-4: FEE REGULATIONS:
(A)    In the absence of provisions to the contrary, all fees and charges for
licenses shall be paid in advance at the time of application to the City
Collector. The fee for such license shall be twenty five dollars ($25.00)
unless otherwise provided by state statutes or as provided elsewhere in this
code.
(B)    When an applicant has not engaged in the business until after the
expiration of part of the current license year, an annual license for the
balance of the calendar year will be issued for a proportionate ( by quarters)
part of the annual fee.
(C)    In no event shall any rebate or refund be made of any license fee, or
part thereof, by reason of death, or departure of the licensee; nor shall any
rebate or refund be made by reason of nonuse of the license or discontinuance
of the operation or conduct or change of ownership of the licensed
establishment, business, or activity.
3-1-5: TERMINATION DATE OF ANNUAL LICENSES:
(A)    All annual licenses shall commence on January 1 each year, and shall
terminate on December 31 of the same year, where no provision to the contrary
is made.
(B)    The City Collector shall notify all annual licensees of license
expiration by December 1 of each year. Failure to make such notification, or
failure of the licensee to receive it shall not excuse the licensee from the
obligation to obtain a new license, nor shall it be a defense based upon
operation without a license.
3-1-6: LICENSE TO BE POSTED:
(A)    It shall be the duty of every licensee conducting business in the City
to keep its license posted in a prominent place on the premises used for such
business at all times.
(B)    No license certificate, plate, badge, tag, emblem, or other insignia
shall be permitted to remain posted or displayed after the period for which the
license was issued has expired.
3-1-7: REPLACEMENT OF LICENSE:
In the event any licensee who has been furnished a license certificate by the
City, shall lose same, it shall be within the discretion of the City to
authorize the issuance of a duplicate certificate with the payment of a fee of
five dollars ($5.00) to the City Collector, unless otherwise specifically
provided.
3-1-8: UNLAWFUL USE OF LICENSE:
(A)    It shall be unlawful for any licensee to loan or give away any license
certificate.
(B)    It shall be unlawful for any person to use or display any license
certificate which has been unlawfully acquired.
3-1-9: CHANGE OF OWNERSHIP: 
Any change in ownership of a business shall require a new license.
3-1-10: BUILDING AND PREMISES:
No license shall be issued for the conduct of any business, if the premises and
building to be used does not fully comply with all applicable City code and
state statutes.
3-1-11: LOCATION:
No license for the operation of a business in the City shall be construed to
permit the operation of a licensed business in more than one location in the
City. A separate license shall be required for each location of a licensed
establishment. For the purposes of this chapter, the existence of a single
location shall be evidenced by the fact that all buildings containing the
principal or accessory uses shall be connected, or shall be located on the same
lot or parcel, shall be operated and managed by the same person or owner, and
shall be an establishment with the same classification.
3-1-12: CHANGE OF LOCATION:
The location of any licensed business may be changed provided that ten (10)
days’ notice is given to the City Collector in the absence of any provision to
the contrary; provided, however, that all applicable City code is complied
with.
3-1-13: REVOCATION OF LICENSE; NOTICE; HEARING:
(A)    Revocation Of License: Any license for a limited time may be revoked by
a majority vote of the City Council at any time during the life of such license
for any violation by the licensee of the provisions relating to the license,
the subject matter of the license, or to the premises occupied; such revocation
may be in addition to any fine imposed.
(B)   Notice Of Revocation: Unless any provision of this code provides to the
contrary, no revocation or suspension of any license issued hereunder shall be
deemed effective until notice thereof has been served personally upon, or
mailed to the named licensee at the address specified in the application.
(C)    Hearing: If within ten (10) days of the date of notice of the revocation
or suspension of any license, the named licensee submits to the City Collector
in writing a request for a hearing concerning such revocation or suspension,
said revocation or suspension shall be suspended until such time as the City
Council shall grant the licensee a special hearing.
(D)    Decision Of City Council: If the City Council after such hearing affirms
the revocation or suspension of said licensee, by a majority vote, the same
shall become immediately effective. If the City Council, by a majority vote,
overrides the revocation, the same shall be deemed null and void.
3-1-14: NUISANCES PROHIBITED:
(A)    Generally: No business or establishment, whether or not licensed, shall
be so conducted or operated as to constitute a nuisance in fact; and no
building, vehicle, structure, yard, lot, premises, or part thereof, shall be
used, kept, maintained, or operated in connection with any business or
establishment so as to occasion any nuisance, or so as to be dangerous to life,
or detrimental to health.
(B)    Unsafe Or Unhealthful Business:
1.   No building or structure, utilized, constructed, or maintained in
connection with any business or occupation, shall evidence an unsanitary,
unsafe, or dangerous condition.
2.   No substance, matter, or thing of any kind whatever, which shall be
dangerous or detrimental to health, shall be allowed to exist in connection
with any business or occupation, or be used in any work or labor performed in
the City.
(C)    Compliance: All licensees shall comply with the provisions in City of
Momence Code with respect to refuse and garbage disposal.
3-1-15: PENALTY:
Any person who conducts a business for which a license is required shall be
required to pay a late penalty of one hundred dollars ($100.00) in addition to
the annual license fee, if the annual license has not been timely obtained on
or before December 31 of each year. In addition to all other remedies available
to the City, any person who violates or fails to comply with any of the
provisions of this chapter, shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars
($100.00) or more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on which a
violation or noncompliance occurs or continues.
SECTION 3: The provisions and sections of this ordinance shall be deemed
separable               and the invalidity of any portion of this ordinance
shall not affect the validity          of the remainder.
SECTION 4: That this ordinance shall be in full force and effect after its
passage,                adoption, and publication as required by law.

ADOPTING ORDINANCE
ORDINANCE NO. 252
   AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING
   THE CITY CODE OF MOMENCE, ILLINOIS
   BE IT ORDAINED by the Mayor and City Council of the City of Momence,
Kankakee County, Illinois, an Illinois Municipal Corporation:
   Section 1: From and after the date of passage of this Ordinance, the City
Code of the City of Momence, Illinois, prepared by Sterling Codifiers, Inc.,
under the direction of the governing body of the City, containing all
ordinances of a general nature in effect at the time of such codification,
shall be accepted in all courts without question as the Official Code and Law
of the City as enacted by the Mayor and City Council.
   Section 2: There is hereby adopted, as a method of perpetual codification,
the loose-leaf type of binding together with the continuous supplement service,
provided by Sterling Codifiers, Inc., whereby each newly adopted ordinance of a
general and permanent nature amending, altering, adding or deleting provisions
of the Official City Code is identified by the proper catchline and is inserted
in the proper place in each of the official copies. Each such new provision
shall become effective upon the passage of the ordinance and the insertion of
the proper replacement pages in the copies of the Code, three (3) copies of
which shall be maintained in the office of the City Clerk, certified as to
correctness and available for inspection at any and all times that said office
is regularly open.
   Section 3: All ordinances of a general nature included in this Official City
Code shall be considered as a continuation of said ordinance provision and the
fact that some provisions have been deliberately eliminated by the governing
body shall not serve to cause any interruption in the continuous effectiveness
of ordinances included in said Official City Code. All ordinances of a special
nature, such as tax levy ordinances, bond ordinances, franchises, vacating
ordinances and annexation ordinances shall continue in full force and effect
unless specifically repealed or amended by a provision of the City Code. Such
ordinances are not intended to be included in the Official City Code.
   Section 4: It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to
change or amend by additions or deletions, any part or portion of such Code, or
to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such
Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the City to be
misrepresented thereby.
Any person, firm or corporation violating this Section shall be punished as
provided in Section
1-4-1 of the City Code of Momence, Illinois.
   Section 5: All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith, are,
to the extent of such conflict, hereby repealed.
   Section 6: This Ordinance shall be in full force and effect upon its
enactment as provided by law.
AYES:
NAYS:
ABSENT:
Passed this 16 day of April, 1979.
Approved this 16 day of April, 1979.
TITLE 1
ADMINISTRATIVE
CHAPTER 1
OFFICIAL CITY CODE
SECTION:
1-1-1: Title
1-1-2: Acceptance
1-1-3: Amendments
1-1-4: Code Alteration
1-1-5: Publication Of Ordinances
1-1-1: TITLE:
Upon adoption by the city council, this code is hereby declared to be and shall
hereafter constitute the official city code of the city of Momence. This code
of ordinances shall be known and cited as the MOMENCE CITY CODE, and it is
hereby published by authority of the council and shall be kept up to date as
provided in section
1-1-3 of this chapter. Any reference to the number of any section contained
herein shall be understood to refer to the position of the same number, its
appropriate chapter and title heading, and to the general penalty clause,
relating thereto, as well as to the section itself, when reference is made to
this code by title in any legal documents. (1979 Code)
1-1-2: ACCEPTANCE:
The city code, as hereby presented in printed form, shall hereafter be received
without further proof in all courts and in all administrative tribunals of this
state as the ordinances of the city of general and permanent effect, except the
excluded ordinances enumerated in section
1-2-1 of this title. (1979 Code)
1-1-3: AMENDMENTS:
Any ordinance amending this code shall set forth the title, chapter and section
number of the section or sections to be amended, and this shall constitute
sufficient compliance with any statutory requirement pertaining to the
amendment or revision by ordinance of any part of this code. All such
amendments or revisions by ordinance shall be immediately forwarded to the
codifiers and the said ordinance material shall be prepared for insertion in
its proper place in each copy of this code. Each such replacement page shall be
properly identified and shall be inserted in each individual copy of this code.
(1979 Code)
1-1-4: CODE ALTERATION:
It shall be deemed unlawful for any person to alter, change, replace or deface
in any way any section or any page of this code in such a manner that the
meaning of any phrase or order may be changed or omitted. Replacement pages may
be inserted according to the official instructions when so authorized by the
city council. The clerk shall see that the replacement pages are properly
inserted in the official copies maintained in the office of the clerk. Any
person having in his custody an official copy of this code shall make every
effort to maintain said code in an up to date and efficient manner. He shall
see to the immediate insertion of new or replacement pages when such are
delivered to him or made available to him through the office of the city clerk.
Said code books, while in actual possession of officials and other interested
persons, shall be and remain the property of the city and shall be returned to
the office of the clerk when directed so to do by order of the city council.
(1979 Code)
1-1-5: PUBLICATION OF ORDINANCES:
All ordinances of the city imposing any fine, penalty, imprisonment or
forfeiture, or making any appropriation may be published by printing said
ordinance in book or pamphlet form by authority of the corporate authorities of
the city.
The city clerk is hereby authorized to publish any ordinance as aforesaid, in
accordance with this section. (Ord., 1961)
CHAPTER 2
SAVING CLAUSE
SECTION:
1-2-1: Repeal Of General Ordinances
1-2-2: Public Utility Ordinances
1-2-3: Court Proceedings
1-2-4: Severability Clause
1-2-1: REPEAL OF GENERAL ORDINANCES:
All general ordinances of the city passed prior to the adoption of this code
are hereby repealed, except such as are included in this code or are by
necessary implication herein reserved from repeal (subject to the saving
clauses contained in the following sections), and excluding the following
ordinances which are not hereby repealed: tax levy ordinances; appropriation
ordinances; ordinances relating to boundaries and annexations; franchise
ordinances and other ordinances granting special rights to persons or
corporations; contract ordinances and ordinances authorizing the execution of a
contract or the issuance of warrants; salary ordinances; ordinances
establishing, naming or vacating streets, alleys or other public places;
improvement ordinances; bond ordinances; ordinances relating to elections;
ordinances relating to the transfer or acceptance of real estate by or from the
city; and all special ordinances. (Ord. 230, 7-3-1978; amd. 1979 Code)
1-2-2: PUBLIC UTILITY ORDINANCES:
No ordinance relating to railroad crossings with streets and other public ways,
or relating to the conduct, duties, service or rates of public utilities shall
be repealed by virtue of the adoption of this code or by virtue of the
preceding section, excepting as this code may contain provisions for such
matters, in which case this code shall be considered as amending such ordinance
or ordinances in respect to such provisions only. (Ord. 230, 7-3-1978; amd.
1979 Code)
1-2-3: COURT PROCEEDINGS:
No new ordinance shall be construed or held to repeal a former ordinance
whether such former ordinance is expressly repealed or not, as to any offense
committed against such former ordinance or as to any act done, any penalty,
forfeiture or punishment so incurred, or any right accrued or claim arising
under the former ordinance, or in any way whatever to affect any such offense
or act so committed or so done, or any penalty, forfeiture or punishment so
incurred or any right accrued or claim arising before the new ordinance takes
effect, save only that the proceedings thereafter shall conform to the
ordinance in force at the time of such proceeding, so far as practicable, if
any penalty, forfeiture or punishment be mitigated by any provision of a new
ordinance, such provision may be, by consent of the party affected, applied to
any judgment announced after the new ordinance takes effect.
This section shall extend to all repeals, either by express words or
implication, whether the repeal is in the ordinance making any new provisions
upon the same subject or in any other ordinance.
Nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed as abating any action now
pending under or by virtue of any general ordinance of the city herein repealed
and the provisions of all general ordinances contained in this code shall be
deemed to be continuing provisions and not a new enactment of the same
provision; nor shall this chapter be deemed as discontinuing, abating,
modifying or altering any penalty accrued or to accrue, or as affecting the
liability of any person, firm or corporation, or as waiving any right of the
city under any ordinance or provision thereof in force at the time of the
adoption of this code. (Ord. 230, 7-3-1978; amd. 1979 Code)
1-2-4: SEVERABILITY CLAUSE:
If any section, subsection, subdivision, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase
of this code or any part thereof is for any reason held to be unconstitutional
or invalid or ineffective by any court of competent jurisdiction, such decision
shall not affect the validity or effectiveness of the remaining portions of
this code, or any part thereof. The city council hereby declares that it would
have passed each section, subsection, subdivision, paragraph, sentence, clause
or phrase thereof irrespective of the fact that any one or more sections,
subsections, subdivisions, paragraphs, sentences, clauses or phrases be
declared unconstitutional, invalid or ineffective. (Ord. 230, 7-3-1978; amd.
1979 Code)
CHAPTER 3
DEFINITIONS
SECTION:
1-3-1: Construction Of Words
1-3-2: Definitions, General
1-3-3: Catchlines
1-3-1: CONSTRUCTION OF WORDS:
   (A)   Words Used: Whenever any word in any section of this code importing
the plural number is used in describing or referring to any matters, parties or
persons, any single matter, party or person shall be deemed to be included
although distributive words may not have been used. When any subject matter,
party or person is referred to by words importing the singular number only or
the masculine gender, several matters, parties or persons and females as well
as males and bodies corporate shall be deemed to be included. The words
"person, firm or corporation" shall be deemed to include any association or
organization of any kind. Words in the present shall include the future. The
words "this title", "this chapter", "this section" or "this subsection" shall
be held and taken to mean the entire enactment, including each and every
chapter, section, subsection or paragraph thereof. The word "city" whenever
used shall be held and taken to mean the city of Momence, Illinois. The words
"written" and "in writing" may include printing, mimeograph, off-set, or any
other reproduction of the words; provided, that these rules of construction
shall not be applied to any section of this code which contains any express
provisions excluding such construction or where the subject matter or content
of such section may be repugnant thereto.
   (B)   Distinction Between "Wholesaler" And "Retailer": In all cases where
the words "wholesaler" or "wholesale dealer" are used in this code, unless
otherwise specifically defined, shall be understood to relate to the sale of
goods, merchandise, articles or things in quantity to persons who purchase for
the purpose of resale as distinguished from a "retail dealer" who sells direct
to the consumer.
   (C)   Officers And Employees: Whenever reference is made in this code to a
city officer or employee by title only, this shall be construed as though
followed by the words "of the city of Momence, Illinois" and shall be taken to
mean the officer or employee of the city having the title mentioned or
performing the duties indicated. (Ord. 230, 7-3-1978)
1-3-2: DEFINITIONS, GENERAL:
Whenever the following words or terms are used in this code they shall have
such meanings herein ascribed to them, unless the context makes such meanings
repugnant thereto:
AGENT: A person acting on behalf of another.
CODE: Unless otherwise specifically stated shall mean this code.
FEE: A sum of money charged by the city for the carrying on of a business,
profession or occupation.
FISCAL YEAR: The "fiscal year" of the city shall commence on May 1 of each and
every year.
KNOWINGLY: Imports only a knowledge that the facts exist which brings the act
or omission within the provisions of this code. It does not require any
knowledge of the unlawfulness of such act or omission.
LICENSE: The permission granted for the carrying on of a business, profession
or occupation.
MISDEMEANOR: Any offense deemed a violation of the provisions of this code
which is a lesser offense than a felony as defined by state law.
MUNICIPAL YEAR: The "municipal year" of the city shall commence on May 1 and
end on April 30 in each and every year.
NEGLIGENT, NEGLECT, NEGLIGENCE AND NEGLIGENTLY: Imports a want of such
attention to the nature of probable consequences of the act or omission as a
prudent man ordinarily bestows in acting in his own concern.
NUISANCE: Anything offensive or obnoxious to the health and welfare of the
inhabitants of the city; or any act or thing repugnant to, or creating a hazard
to, or having a detrimental effect on the property of another person or to the
community.
OCCUPANT: Applied to a building or land, shall include any person who occupies
the whole or any part of such building or land whether alone or with others.
OFFENSE: Any act forbidden by any provision of this code or the omission of any
act required by the provisions of this code.
OPERATOR: The person who is in charge of any operation, business or profession.
OWNER: Applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint
owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or lessee of the whole or of a part of
such building or land.
PERSON: Any natural individual, firm, trust, partnership, association or
corporation in his or its own capacity or as administrator, conservator,
executor, trustee, receiver or other representative appointed by the court.
Whenever the word "person" is used in any section of this code prescribing a
penalty or fine as applied to partnerships or associations, the word shall
include the partners or members thereof, and such word as applied to
corporations shall include the officers, agents or employees thereof who are
responsible for any violation of said section.
PERSONAL PROPERTY: Shall include every description of money, goods, chattels,
effects, evidence of rights in action and all written instruments by which any
pecuniary obligation, right or title to property is created, acknowledged,
transferred, increased, defeated, discharged or diminished and every right or
interest therein.
RIGHT OF WAY: The privilege of the immediate use of the roadway or other
property.
STREET: Shall include alleys, lanes, courts, boulevards, public ways, public
squares, public places and sidewalks.
TENANT: Applied to a building or land, shall include any person who occupies
the whole or any part of such building or land whether alone or with others.
WILFULLY: When applied to the intent with which an act is done or omitted,
implies simply a purpose or willingness to commit the act or make the omission
referred to. It does not require any intent to violate law, or to injure
another, or to acquire an advantage. (Ord. 199, 2-6-1978; amd. 1979 Code; Ord.
541, 8-4-2003)
1-3-3: CATCHLINES:
The catchlines of the several sections of this code are intended as mere
catchwords to indicate the content of the section and shall not be deemed or
taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor unless
expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections,
including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. (1979 Code)
CHAPTER 4
GENERAL PENALTY
SECTION:
1-4-1: General Penalty
1-4-2: Application Of Provisions
1-4-3: Presumption Of Liability
1-4-4: Liability Of Officers
1-4-1: GENERAL PENALTY:
   (A)   Penalty: Whenever in this Code an act, or omission is prohibited, or
declared to be unlawful, or an offense, or a violation of this Code, or
whenever in this Code the doing of an act is required, or the failure is
declared to be unlawful, or an offense, or a violation of this Code, where no
specific penalty is provided, therefor, the violation of any such provision of
this Code is hereby declared to be an offense, and shall be punishable by a
fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and not to exceed seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) per day, or as established in the City of
Momence's approved fines and fees list, located in subsection (B) of this
section. At the discretion of the City, a person may be allowed to perform
community service, in lieu of fines, or be required to attend a City
adjudication hearing. (Ord. 723, 9-19-2011)
   (B)   Fine Schedule:

1-4-2: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
The penalty provided in this chapter shall be applicable to every section of
this Code the same as though it were a part of each and every separate section.
Any person convicted of a violation of any section of this Code where a duty is
prescribed or obligation imposed, or where any action which is of a continuing
nature is forbidden or is declared to be unlawful, shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor. A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day such
duty or obligation remains unperformed or such act continues, unless otherwise
specifically provided in this Code.
In all cases where the same offense is made punishable or is created by
different clauses or sections of this Code, the Prosecuting Officer may elect
under which to proceed; but not more than one recovery shall be had against the
same person for the same offense; provided, that the revocation of a license or
permit shall not be considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar any other
penalty being enforced.
Whenever the doing of any act or the omission to do any act constitutes a
breach of any section or provision of this Code and there shall be no fine or
penalty specifically declared for such breach, the provisions of this chapter
shall apply.
Whenever the doing of any act or the omission to do any act constitutes a
nuisance, or is a violation of the zoning or subdivision regulations of the
City 1 , in addition to any fine that may be imposed for said breach, the City
Attorney or any attorney retained by the City Council may petition for
injunctive relief to enjoin the doing of any act or the omission to do any act
which constitutes a nuisance or is a violation of the zoning or subdivision
regulations of the City. (Ord. 230, 7-3-1978; amd. 1979 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See titles 9 and 10 of this Code.
1-4-3: PRESUMPTION OF LIABILITY:
The occupant of any premises, and the owner of unoccupied premises, upon which
a violation of this Code is apparent, the owner of any object or material
placed or remaining anywhere in violation of this Code, and the occupant and
owner of any premises served by any excavation connection or structure
illegally made or erected, shall be deemed prima facie responsible for the
violation so evidenced and subject to the penalty provided therefor. (Ord. 230,
7-3-1978; amd. 1979 Code)
1-4-4: LIABILITY OF OFFICERS:
No provision of this Code designating the duties of any officer or employee
shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine
or penalty provided for a failure to perform such duty, unless the intent of
the Council to impose such fine or penalty on such officer or employee is
specifically and clearly expressed in the section creating the duty. (Ord. 230,
7-3-1978; amd. 1979 Code)
CHAPTER 5
CITY COUNCIL
SECTION:
1-5-1: Council Established; Vacancy
1-5-2: Term Of Office
1-5-3: Qualifications
1-5-4: Meetings
1-5-5: Standing Committees
1-5-6: Duties Of Standing Committees
1-5-7: Quorum; Failure To Attend
1-5-8: Rules And Regulations
1-5-9: Election Of Officers
1-5-10: Electronic Attendance
1-5-11: Public Participation
1-5-1: COUNCIL ESTABLISHED; VACANCY:
The city council shall consist of the mayor and two (2) aldermen from each
ward. Said council shall be the judge of the election and qualification of its
own members. If a vacancy occurs in the office of alderman by reason of
resignation, failure to elect or qualify, death, permanent physical or mental
disability, conviction of a disqualifying crime, abandonment of office, or
removal from office or of residence from the ward, or otherwise, the vacancy
may be filled at the next succeeding general election for aldermen at which
time the vacancy shall be filled for the unexpired balance of the term. A
vacancy for alderman shall not be filled by special election in compliance with
65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-4-14. The mayor, with the advice and consent
of the city council, may appoint a person to serve as alderman in the vacancy
until the next general election, as provided in this section and until the
person elected qualifies. (Ord. 199, 2-6-1978)
1-5-2: TERM OF OFFICE:
The aldermen of the city shall hold their offices for the terms of four (4)
years, and until their successors are elected and qualified. (Ord. 199, 2-6-
1978)
1-5-3: QUALIFICATIONS:
No person shall be eligible to the office of alderman unless he is a qualified
elector and resides within the ward for which he was elected nor shall he be
eligible if he is in arrears in the payment of any tax or other liability due
the city; nor shall he be directly or indirectly interested in any contract
whatever to which the city is a party; nor shall he be eligible if he has been
convicted of malfeasance, bribery or corrupt practices or crime; nor shall he
be eligible to any office, the salary of which is payable out of the city
treasury, if at the time of his appointment he is a member of the city council;
nor shall any member of the city council at the time hold any other office
under the city government; nor shall he be, either directly or indirectly,
individually, or as a member of a firm, engaged in any business transaction
(other than official) with the city, through its mayor or any of its authorized
boards, agents or attorneys, where any money is to be paid, directly or
indirectly, out of the city treasury to such member, firm or firms. (Ord. 199,
2-6-1978)
1-5-4: MEETINGS:
   (A)   Regular Meetings: The regular stated meetings of the city council
shall be held in the council chamber at the city hall on the first and third
Mondays of each and every month. The meetings shall be commenced at the hour of
seven thirty o'clock (7:30) P.M., Central Standard Time or between the dates
when Central Daylight Time is in effect, at seven thirty o'clock (7:30) P.M.,
Central Daylight Time. If at any time the first or third Monday shall happen to
be a legal holiday, the council shall meet at the same hour on the next day
following. Adjourned meetings may be held at such time or times as may be
determined by the council.
   (B)   Special Meetings: Special meetings of the council may be called by the
mayor or any four (4) aldermen whenever, in their discretion, they may deem if
necessary. The meeting shall be called in the following manner: The mayor or
four (4) aldermen, as the case may be, shall file in the office of the city
clerk a statement in writing setting forth the object and purpose of the
special meeting and directing the clerk to give notice of same. Upon the filing
of the statement the clerk shall cause to be served personally upon each member
of the council a notice of the special meeting setting forth the object and
purpose thereof and the time of holding the same. No business other than that
mentioned in the call shall be transacted at any special meeting unless three-
fourths (3/4) of all elected aldermen shall be present and vote. (Ord. 199, 2-
6-1978)
1-5-5: STANDING COMMITTEES:
It shall be the duty of the mayor at the first regular meeting of the council
in May in each year, or as soon thereafter as may be, to appoint the standing
committees of the city council which shall be as follows:
First   Administration and finance, one member each ward
Second  Streets and alleys, one member each ward
Third   Police, one member each ward
Fourth  Local improvements and buildings, one member each ward
Fifth   Election and ordinance, one member each ward
Sixth   Water and sewer, one member each ward
Seventh Public relations, one member each ward
Eight   Economic development, one member each ward
 
(Ord. 199, 2-6-1978; amd. Ord. 893, 5-5-2025)
1-5-6: DUTIES OF STANDING COMMITTEES:
It shall be the duty of the standing committees of the city council to keep a
close watch of the affairs of their respective departments of the city
government. They shall have the general management, control and supervision
over all works and things ordered to be made or done by the council in their
respective departments and they shall make reports to the council of whatever
facts may be deemed of importance. Each committee shall promptly and thoroughly
investigate and report in writing upon all matters referred to it by the
council and do and perform such other and further duties as the council may
from time to time by ordinance, resolution or motion, prescribe. (Ord. 199, 2-
6-1978)
1-5-7: QUORUM; FAILURE TO ATTEND:
A majority of the aldermen elected shall constitute a quorum to do business,
but a smaller number may adjourn from time to time, and may compel the
attendance of absentees, under the penalties prescribed herein.
In case of the want of a quorum at any time of the city council, in case a
majority of the members present shall direct, the mayor or presiding officer
shall direct the chief of police or any police officer to go out and arrest and
bring in any and all absent members that can be found in the city, who are not
unable through sickness to attend; and any member who purposely absents himself
from the city to avoid attending any meeting of the council, or being in the
city, conceals himself from such officer or refuses to be brought in when found
may, with concurrence of two-thirds (2/3) of the aldermen elect, be expelled,
in which event his seat shall be deemed vacant and shall be filled by an
election as in other cases of vacancy. (Ord. 199, 2-6-1978)
1-5-8: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
   (A)   Members Required To Vote: Every member of the council shall vote upon
all questions in which they are not directly or personally interested, which
may be brought before the council for its action in such manner as to require a
vote to be taken thereon unless such member be excused by a vote of two-thirds
(2/3) of all the other members present; and in case any member shall refuse to
vote who shall not have been thus excused shall be considered as having voted
with the majority on such question and his vote shall be so recorded.
   (B)   Required Majority Vote: The yeas and nays shall be taken upon the
passage of all ordinances and on all propositions to create any liability
against the city or for the expenditure or appropriation of its money, and in
all other cases at the request of any member which shall be entered on the
journal of the proceedings; and the concurrence of a majority of all the
members elected in the city council shall be necessary to the passage of any
such ordinance or proposition; provided, the city shall require three-fourths
(3/4) of all the aldermen elect to sell any city property.
   (C)   Passing Over Veto: In case the mayor shall veto any ordinance or any
part of an ordinance and return the same to the council together with his
objections thereto, the vote by which the same was passed shall be reconsidered
by the council; and if, after such reconsideration, two-thirds (2/3) of all the
aldermen elected to the city council shall agree by yeas and nays to pass the
same, it shall go into effect, notwithstanding the mayor may refuse to approve
thereof. The vote to pass the same over the mayor's veto shall be taken by yeas
and nays and entered on the journal.
   (D)   Reconsideration Of Vote: No vote of the city council shall be
reconsidered or rescinded at any special meeting thereof unless at such special
meeting there be present as large a number of aldermen as were present when
such vote was taken.
   (E)   Committee Reports:
      1.   Every committee of the city council, in reporting upon any subject
referred to it, shall attach to its report all papers or documents in the
possession of the committee relative to the matter so referred.
      2.   Any report of a committee of the city council shall be deferred, for
final action thereof, at the next regular meeting of the same after the report
is made, upon the request of any two (2) aldermen present. (Ord. 199, 2-6-1978)
1-5-9: ELECTION OF OFFICERS:
Beginning with the regular election of municipal officers on April 7, 1981, and
for each regular municipal election thereafter all persons elected to a
municipal office: mayor, city treasurer, city clerk and members of the city
council, shall be sworn in and assume their respective duties at the first
regular meeting of the city council in the month of May immediately following
their election in April. (Ord. 268, 4-6-1981)
1-5-10: ELECTRONIC ATTENDANCE:
   (A)   The member requesting electronic attendance, such as by telephone,
video or internet connection, should notify the mayor, city clerk, or city
collector, at least twenty four (24) hours before the meeting, unless
impractical, so that necessary communications equipment can be arranged.
Inability to make the necessary technical arrangements will result in denial of
a request for electronic attendance.
   (B)   The city clerk, after receiving the electronic attendance request,
shall inform the city council of the request for electronic attendance.
   (C)   The following conditions must be met before a member of the city
council may attend any open meeting electronically 1 .
      1.   After a roll call establishing that a quorum is physically present,
the presiding officer shall call for a motion before one or more members will
be permitted to attend by electronic means. The presiding officer will specify
the reason entitling the absent member, or members, to attend electronically.
The motion must be approved by a vote of a majority of the members present. The
presiding officer shall declare the requesting member, or members, present. The
vote may not be reconsidered.
      2.   If more than one member participates by electronic means, the absent
members may not meet at the same remote location if their joint presence at the
remote location would constitute a violation of the Illinois open meetings act.
      3.   The member must assert one of the following three (3) reasons why he
or she is unable to physically attend the meeting:
         (a)   The member cannot attend because of personal illness or
disability; or
         (b)   The member cannot attend because of employment purposes or the
business of the city of Momence; or
         (c)   The member cannot attend because of a family or other emergency.
      4.   The member seeking participation shall be available on the telephone
or other communication device not less than five (5) minutes prior to the
meeting.
      5.   Costs associated with the member's participation shall be borne
solely by the member and not the city.
   (D)   The member participating electronically and other members of the city
council must be able to communicate effectively, and members of the audience
must be able to hear all communications at the meeting site. Before allowing
electronic attendance at any meeting, the city of Momence shall provide
equipment adequate to accomplish this objective at the meeting site.
   (E)   If the presiding officer of the public body is attending the meeting
by electronic means, then the person who acts in the absence of the presiding
officer shall chair the meeting. If there is none, then the presiding officer
shall appoint a member of the public body who is physically present at the
meeting to serve as chair of the meeting. The appointment of a chair shall be
subject to the consent of the public body. The presiding officer who is
participating by electronic means shall be authorized to participate in the
meeting to the extent authorized by law or ordinance except for those acts
involved with chairing the meeting.
   (F)   Any member attending electronically shall be considered an off site
attendee and counted as present electronically for that meeting. The meeting
minutes shall also reflect and state specifically whether each member is
physically present or present by electronic means.
   (G)   Any member permitted to attend electronically will be able to express
his or her comments during the meeting and participate in the same capacity as
those members physically present, subject to all general meeting guidelines and
procedures previously adopted and adhered to. The member attending
electronically shall be heard, considered, and counted as to any vote taken.
Accordingly, the name of any member attending electronically shall be called
during any vote taken, and his or her vote counted and recorded by the city
clerk and placed in the minutes for the corresponding meeting. A member
attending electronically may leave a meeting and return as in the case of any
member, provided the member attending electronically shall announce his or her
leaving and returning.
   (H)   No member of a public body who is participating electronically in a
public meeting shall be permitted to participate in any portion of the meeting
which is closed to the public, including, but not limited to, executive
sessions which are closed to the public under the applicable provisions of the
open meetings act, 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 120/1 et seq.
   (I)   No member of a public body may participate electronically in a public
meeting more than twelve (12) times in a fiscal year. (Ord. 748, 10-15-2012)
 
Notes
1 1. As defined in 5 ILCS 120/7.
1-5-11: PUBLIC PARTICIPATION:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to address or attempt to address
any regular meeting of the city council except in compliance with this section.
Public participation shall be permitted during the following portions of a
public meeting:
      1.   Citizen forum.
      2.   Public hearing.
      3.   Invited speakers.
   (B)   Public participation shall not be permitted during any meetings or
portions of meeting which are deemed closed sessions under the open meetings
act, 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 120/1 et seq., as amended.
   (C)   The presiding officer may impose reasonable limitations on public
participation at public meetings, such as barring repetitious, irrelevant,
immaterial, or inappropriate comments or testimony. The presiding officer shall
have the authority to halt or suspend the public communications/hearing to a
later date due to the duration of the public forum/hearing or lack of
compliance with this section. In addition to those portions of a meeting set
aside for public participation, the presiding officer shall have the discretion
to permit public comment at any other time during a meeting, subject to the
provisions of this section.
   (D)   Persons wishing to speak during the public participation portion of a
city council meeting shall sign in ten (10) minutes prior to the start of the
meeting stating their name, and item on which they wish to speak. All items
must pertain to city business. All speakers shall comply with this section and
rulings of the presiding officer. Speakers shall be called by name by the
presiding officer.
   (E)   Speakers shall identify themselves before beginning their comments or
questions. Speakers shall provide their comments or questions, and provide any
supporting documentation and/or evidence they may wish to submit. Speakers
shall refrain from engaging in debates, directing threats or personal attacks
at the presiding officer, city council, city staff, other speakers or members
of the audience. The presiding officer and city council shall have no
obligation to respond to any comments or questions raised by members of the
public.
   (F)   Members of the audience shall refrain from applauding, cheering, or
booing during or at the conclusion of remarks made by any speaker, staff
member, city council member, or presiding officer.
   (G)   Groups of residents should, whenever possible, consolidate their
comments and avoid repetition through the use of representative speakers.
   (H)   All speakers shall limit their comments to approximately five (5)
minutes.
   (I)   The petitioner of an agenda item is a person or entity with a direct
interest in a decision. The petitioner may proceed with a brief presentation of
the petition for no more than ten (10) minutes.
      1.   Speakers may comment or ask questions on the agenda item after the
presentation of the petition provided they comply with all the applicable
provisions of this section.
      2.   The petitioner shall have no more than five (5) minutes to reply to
comments or questions. Public participation after the petitioner's reply shall
be prohibited unless the presiding officer directs otherwise.
      3.   The presiding officer and city council may, but need not ask
questions of the petitioner and speakers at the conclusion of their comments.
      4.   The city council may then deliberate upon the petition. No
additional comment may be made by the public or the petitioner except upon the
express permission of the presiding officer.
   (J)   The rules applicable to the public forum shall generally apply to
public hearings.
   (K)   Any citizen may address the city council by invitation of the
presiding officer or a majority of the city council present. Speakers invited
to participate shall be subject to such limitations as the presiding officer or
majority of the city council shall prescribe. In the absence of other
restrictions, such speakers shall be governed by the same rules which govern
the public forum. (Ord. 799, 10-5-2015)
CHAPTER 6
MAYOR
SECTION:
1-6-1: Qualifications, Term Of Office
1-6-2: Oath; Bond
1-6-3: Powers And Duties
1-6-4: Vacancy In Office (Rep. by Ord. 645, 4-21-2008)
1-6-5: Mayor Pro Tem
1-6-1: QUALIFICATIONS, TERM OF OFFICE:
The mayor shall be the chief executive officer of the city. He shall be a
citizen of the United States, a qualified elector, reside within the city
limits, and shall hold his office for four (4) years and until his successor is
elected and qualified. (Ord. 200, 1-16-1978)
1-6-2: OATH; BOND:
The mayor, before entering upon the duties of his office, shall take the oath
prescribed for other city officers and shall execute a bond to the city in the
penal sum of three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) conditioned for the faithful
performance of the duties of the office. (Ord. 200, 1-16-1978)
1-6-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   (A)   General: The mayor shall devote so much of his time to the duties of
his office as a faithful and efficient discharge thereof may require. He shall
take care that all the regulations of the city be duly enforced, respected and
observed. He shall preside at all meetings of the city council, but shall not
vote except in case of a tie, when he shall give the deciding vote. He shall
preserve order and decorum and generally do and perform all acts and things
which are enjoined upon him by the laws of the state of Illinois and the
ordinances of the city.
   (B)   Appointments; Filling Vacancies: The mayor shall appoint, by and with
the advice and consent of the city council, all officers of the city whose
appointments are not otherwise provided for by law; and whenever a vacancy
shall occur in any office which by law or ordinance he is empowered and
required to fill, he shall at the next regular meeting of the city council
occurring not less than ten (10) days after such vacancy communicate to the
city council the name of his appointee to such office, and pending the
concurrence of the council in such appointment, he may designate some suitable
person to discharge the functions of such office.
   (C)   Supervise Conduct Of Officers: The mayor shall supervise the conduct
of all officers of the city and see that they faithfully and efficiently
discharge the duties of the respective offices. He shall inquire into all
reasonable complaints made against them and cause all their neglects or
violations of duty to be promptly corrected and he shall, in case he becomes
satisfied that any officer wilfully neglects or violates his duty, cause such
officer to be prosecuted and punished. He shall from time to time give the
council such information relative to the affairs of the city as he may deem
proper, and recommend for said council's consideration any measures that he may
deem expedient, tending to the well being, security or improvements of the
city.
   (D)   Removal Of Officers: The mayor shall have the power to remove any
officer appointed by him on any formal charge whenever he shall be of the
opinion that the interests of the city demand such removal but he shall report
the reasons of such removal to the city council at the next regular meeting
thereof to be held not less than five (5) days after such removal; and if the
mayor shall fail or refuse to file with the city clerk a statement of the
reasons for such removal, or if the city council, by a two- thirds (2/3) vote
of all its members authorized by law to be elected, by yeas and nays, to be
entered upon its record, disapprove of such removal, such officer shall
thereupon become restored to the office from which he was so removed; but he
shall give new bonds and take a new oath of office. No officer shall be removed
a second time for the same offense.
   (E)   Ordinances; Approval, Veto: The mayor shall carefully inspect all
ordinances passed by the city council and affix his official signature to such
as he may approve and return them to the city clerk within ten (10) days after
their passage. All ordinances passed as aforesaid which do not meet his
approval shall be returned to the council with his objections thereto in
writing at the next regular meeting of the council occurring not less than five
(5) days after the passage thereof. Such veto may extend to any one or more
items or appropriations contained in any ordinance, or to the entire ordinance,
and in case the veto only extends to a part of such ordinance the residue
thereof shall take effect and be in force. In case the mayor shall fail to
return any ordinance with his objections thereto, by the time aforesaid, he
shall be deemed to have approved such ordinance and the same shall take effect
accordingly.
   (F)   Commissions, Warrants: The mayor shall sign all commissions and
warrants granted, issued or drawn by the order of the city council, or
authorized by the ordinances of the city. In all contracts where the city is a
party, he shall sign the same on behalf of the city and it shall be his special
duty to see that the other contracting party faithfully complies with the
contract, and on all suits wherein the city is a party, it shall be the duty of
the mayor to advise with the city attorney in prosecuting or defending the
same, as the case may be.
   (G)   Licenses; Issuance And Revocation: The mayor shall grant licenses, for
purposes authorized by any provision of the city, to such persons duly
qualified according to ordinance, as he may deem proper, unless the city
council shall otherwise provide, and may revoke the same at pleasure; provided,
that licenses for the operation of saloons or dramshops shall first be
authorized by the city council.
   (H)   Additional Duties: In addition to the above and foregoing, the mayor
shall perform all such duties as may be prescribed by law, or by the city
ordinances and shall take care that the laws and ordinances of the city are
enforced. (Ord. 200, 1-16-1978)
1-6-4: VACANCY IN OFFICE:
(Rep. by Ord. 645, 4-21-2008)
1-6-5: MAYOR PRO TEM:
During a temporary absence or disability of the mayor, the city council shall
elect one of its number to act as mayor pro tem who, during such absence or
disability, shall possess all the powers of the mayor. (Ord. 200, 1-16-1978)
CHAPTER 7
CITY CLERK
SECTION:
1-7-1: Election, Qualifications
1-7-2: Bond
1-7-3: Records Of Council
1-7-4: General Duties
1-7-5: Records Given To Successor
1-7-1: ELECTION, QUALIFICATIONS:
The city clerk shall be elected and shall hold office as provided by law and
the provisions of this code. He shall be a qualified elector and resident of
the city. (Ord. 201, 1-16-1978)
1-7-2: BOND:
Before entering upon his duties, the city clerk elect shall give bond to the
city with two (2) or more resident sureties, to be approved by the city
council, in the sum of not less than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00),
conditioned for the faithful discharge of his duties as such city clerk, and
that he will safely keep and pay over all money intrusted to his keeping as
such city clerk. (Ord. 201, 1-16-1978)
1-7-3: RECORDS OF COUNCIL:
It shall be the duty of the city clerk to attend all meetings of the city
council, keep a full and correct journal of its proceedings and of all
ordinances which the council may ordain. He shall carefully preserve all books,
records and papers which may come into his possession belonging to the city and
do and perform all other duties which may be required of him by ordinance of
the city or by the city council or mayor. (Ord. 201, 1-16-1978)
1-7-4: GENERAL DUTIES:
The city clerk shall perform the following duties:
   (A)   Receive and collect all monies, except taxes, due or payable to the
city whether for fines, water rents or for any other purpose whatsoever, and on
the first Monday following the date upon which such monies are received by the
city clerk, he shall pay over all of such monies to the city treasurer who
shall thereupon issue to such clerk a receipt for all monies so paid to him.
   (B)   Keep a full and correct record of all of the financial transactions of
the city and of the waterworks system of the city including a record of all
monies due and owing the city, by whom and what claim, account or demand owing,
and a record of all sums of money received by him for the city, the date when
received, the amount received, the name of the party making the payment and the
account to which each payment was credited; a record of the dates when such
monies were paid over to the city treasurer; and a full and complete account
with every person using city water.
   (C)   Keep a full and correct record of every order granted by the city
council, the amount thereof, the name of the person for whom issued and the
claim, account or demand for which issued.
   (D)   At the regular monthly meeting of the city council, or whenever
requested by the council or the financial committee thereof, make a full and
correct report of the condition of the city's finances and of all monies
received by him and of all orders issued by him since making his last report or
during such other period during his term of office as shall be inquired of.
(Ord. 201, 1-16-1978)
1-7-5: RECORDS GIVEN TO SUCCESSOR:
At the expiration of his term of office the city clerk shall turn over and
deliver to his successor in office all books, records, papers and other
property belonging to the city over which as city clerk he is custodian. (Ord.
201, 1-16-1978)
CHAPTER 8
CITY TREASURER
SECTION:
1-8-1: Appointment
1-8-2: Bond
1-8-3: Receipt, Disbursement Of City Monies
1-8-4: Reports To City Council
1-8-5: Treasurer's Records
1-8-1: APPOINTMENT:
The City Treasurer shall be appointed and shall be selected from time to time
in the same manner as other appointed officers of the city, which would be the
salary of the appointed City Treasurer shall be that otherwise established by
ordinance or other official municipal action. (Ord. 853, 9-8-2020)
1-8-2: BOND:
Before entering upon the duties of an appointed Treasurer, such person so
appointed shall furnish a good and sufficient bond to the City to be approved
by the city council in the penal sum of not less than five thousand dollars
($5,000.00), signed by two (2) responsible parties who are residents of the
city, conditioned that he will well and truly perform all of the duties of the
office of city treasurer and that he will fully account for all monies received
by him as such treasurer. (Ord. 202, 1-16-1978; amd. Ord. 853, 9-8-2020)
1-8-3: RECEIPT, DISBURSEMENT OF CITY MONIES:
The city treasurer shall receive all monies belonging to the city, collected by
the city clerk. He shall also receive the city taxes and shall keep a full and
correct record of all the financial transactions of the city, including a
proper and regular account of all monies received and disbursed; of whom
received and to whom paid out; for what claim, account or demand received or
paid out; and the date of such receipt or payment.
The city treasurer shall in no case pay out money except in pursuance of an
order signed by the city council countersigned by the city clerk.
All checks disbursing city monies shall require the signature of two (2) of the
following elected officials: the mayor, the city treasurer, or the city clerk.
(Ord. 588, 5-2-2005)
1-8-4: REPORTS TO CITY COUNCIL:
   (A)   Monthly Report: The city treasurer shall, at the second regular
meeting of the city council in each month, exhibit to the council an abstract
of his accounts of all monies received and paid out.
   (B)   Annual Report: At the second city council meeting after the budget is
approved in each year the city treasurer shall exhibit to the city council, and
more often if required, a full and detailed account of all receipts and
expenditures since the date of the last annual report, all monies due to the
city and the state of the city's treasury. The report herein provided for shall
be filed with the city clerk and shall be published in some newspaper published
in Kankakee County. (Ord. 650, 7-21-2008)
1-8-5: TREASURER'S RECORDS:
The treasurer's records, including monthly invoices, city checks, documents
concerning receipts and expenditures and any other treasurer's records, shall
be maintained and kept at the Momence city hall. The treasurer's records shall
not be removed from the Momence city hall without action and consent by the
city council. (Ord. 591, 5-2-2005)
CHAPTER 9
CITY COLLECTOR
SECTION:
1-9-1: Office Established; Appointment; Term; Vacancy
1-9-2: Oath; Bond
1-9-3: Books And Accounts
1-9-4: Monthly Report
1-9-1: OFFICE ESTABLISHED; APPOINTMENT; TERM; VACANCY:
The office of the city collector is hereby established in the city. The mayor,
with the advice and consent of the city council, shall annually appoint a city
collector who shall hold his office for a term not exceeding one year, or until
his successor is appointed and qualified. The mayor and city council may at any
time fill any vacancy that may occur in the office of city collector. (Ord.
123, 5-1-1916)
1-9-2: OATH; BOND:
The city collector, before entering upon the duties of his office shall take
the oath prescribed for city officers and shall execute a bond to the city in
such sum as the mayor and city council shall decide from time to time, with at
least two (2) good and sufficient sureties to be approved by the city council,
conditioned for the faithful performance of the duties of his office and the
payment of all money received by him according to law and ordinances of the
city. (Ord. 123, 5-1-1916)
1-9-3: BOOKS AND ACCOUNTS:
The city collector shall keep his books and accounts in such a manner as to
show with entire accuracy all monies received and disbursed by him for the
city, stating from whom and on what account received and to whom and on what
account paid out, and the same shall be at all times open to the mayor and
clerk and the finance committee or any member of the city council. (Ord. 123,
5-1-1916)
1-9-4: MONTHLY REPORT:
The city collector shall make a monthly report on all delinquent bills and all
miscellaneous monies collected, said report to be submitted at the second
meeting of the month. (Min., 1-18-1960)
CHAPTER 10
CITY ATTORNEY
SECTION:
1-10-1: Bond
1-10-2: Duties
1-10-3: Special Assessment Proceedings
1-10-1: BOND:
Before entering upon the duties of his office, the city attorney shall execute
a bond in the amount of two hundred dollars ($200.00) with approval of the city
council. (Ord., 6-15-1891)
1-10-2: DUTIES:
The city attorney shall perform such duties as the council, by ordinance or
resolution, may prescribe from time to time. (Ord., 5-27-1895)
1-10-3: SPECIAL ASSESSMENT PROCEEDINGS:
The city attorney shall have no authority whatever to appear for the city in
any special assessment proceedings for waterworks or anything relating thereto
without a resolution passed by a majority of all the members elect. The city
council, by resolution, shall designate such officer or attorney as said
council deems proper to represent the city in all special assessment
proceedings, and none other shall represent the city. (Ord., 5-27-1895)
CHAPTER 11
CITY OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES
SECTION:
1-11-1: Salaries
1-11-2: Police Department Rules And Regulations
1-11-3: Director Of Public Works
1-11-1: SALARIES:
The salaries and compensation for elected officials, appointed officials and
City employees shall be as set from time to time by the Mayor and Council.
   (A)   The salary of the Mayor of the City is hereby set at two hundred
dollars ($200.00) per regular meeting or special meeting attended.
   (B)   The salary of the Liquor Commissioner of the City is hereby set at one
hundred twenty five dollars ($125.00) per month.
   (C)   The salary of the City Clerk is hereby set at two hundred dollars
($200.00) per regular meeting or special meeting attended. (Ord. 653, 10-20-
2008)
   (D)   The salary of the City Treasurer is hereby set at two hundred dollars
($200.00) per regular meeting or special meeting attended. The Treasurer does
not have to attend the first meeting of the month in order to be compensated.
(Ord. 653, 10-20-2008; amd. Ord. 831, 11-6-2017)
   (E)   The salary of the Aldermen of the City is hereby set at one hundred
dollars ($100.00) per regular meeting or special meeting attended. Aldermen
shall receive no compensation for any regular meeting or special meeting they
fail to attend if they miss more than two (2) meetings in any calendar year.
   (F)   The compensation fixed by this section shall be effective as to each
respective office on the first day of the term for that office when said term
begins at least one hundred eighty (180) days after the date this section
becomes law. The compensation established by prior ordinance for each office
shall continue to be paid to that office until the compensation set forth in
this section becomes effective as to that office. (Ord. 653, 10-20-2008)
1-11-2: POLICE DEPARTMENT RULES AND REGULATIONS:
   (A)   Authority: The Chief of Police is the Chief Executive Officer of the
department and the final departmental authority in all matters of policy,
operation, and discipline subject to these rules and regulations. He shall
plan, direct, coordinate, and control all officers and activities of the
department and shall be responsible for the continued operation of the
department. The Chief may promulgate reasonable orders relating to the
operation of the department and its officers not inconsistent with these rules.
He shall keep an inventory of all property of the department and shall maintain
all other records deemed necessary for the safe and orderly operation of the
department. In the absence of the Chief of Police or in the case of his
inability to act, the next officer in command shall be established by the Mayor
of Momence with the advice and consent of the City Council and shall exercise
the powers and duties of the Chief of Police.
   (B)   Orders: Officers of the department shall obey and properly execute all
lawful orders from the Chief of Police or the officer in command. Orders may be
oral unless the Chief proposes to establish a rule of general application, and
then such orders shall be in writing and posted on the police bulletin board.
Failure of any officer to obey a lawful order shall be considered
insubordination and subject said officer to the discipline hereinafter set out.
An officer who receives an unlawful or improper order shall report the same to
the Chairman of the Police Committee of the City Council. If the Chairman is of
the opinion that such order is unlawful or improper, he shall call a meeting of
the Police Committee for the purpose of considering the allowance or revocation
of said order. Said meeting shall be called within ten (10) days and the Chief
of Police and the officer objecting to the order shall be present at such
meeting. The order shall be obeyed until overruled. (Ord. 328, 7-21-1986)
   (C)   Personnel Matters:
      1.   No person shall become a member of the Momence Police Department
except upon making application for employment in writing on a City of Momence
employment form and upon exhibiting satisfactory evidence to the Police
Committee of the City of Momence that he or she qualifies in all respects to be
a police officer within the City of Momence and State of Illinois. All police
officers, other than those officers who shall be employed on a full time basis,
shall be qualified to enter and successfully complete any training mandated by
the Illinois Law Enforcement Training Standards Board. The aforesaid hiring
standard, particularly with respect to part time police officers employed by
the City of Momence, Illinois, shall be submitted to the Illinois Law
Enforcement Training Standards Board, as required by statute. Upon the Police
Committee determining the need for a police officer and the passing on the
fitness of the proposed employee to serve in such capacity, the Police
Committee shall recommend the hiring of said person to the City Council. At the
time of hiring, the City Council, or the current labor contract, shall set the
wages of said officer. (Ord. 701, 1-3-2011)
      2.   All persons hired by the City Council as a police officer of the
City of Momence shall be on probation for a period of twelve (12) to eighteen
(18) months. At the time of hiring, the City Council shall determine and fix
the period of probation and communicate said fact to the officer. The officer
may at any time during said period be fired for any reason by the City Council
and said fact shall further be communicated to the officer at the time of his
or her hiring.
      3.   Whenever a condition exists which is deemed by the Chief of Police
to be an emergency, regular tours of duty may be extended and personal leaves
may be canceled.
      4.   Any officer injured while on duty shall when able, considering the
severity of the injury, report the same orally to the Police Committee of the
City of Momence and shall within five (5) days thereafter file a written report
with the Chief of Police advising him of the nature and circumstances
surrounding the injury. Any injured officer absent from work for more than one
week as a result of said injury shall submit to an examination by a physician
selected by the Chief of Police to determine the nature and extent of said
injury. No officer so examined shall return to work until said physician gives
his written opinion to the Chief of Police that the officer is capable of
returning to work.
      5.   Any officer absent from work on account of illness or injury shall
notify the Chief of Police as soon as the illness or injury occurs. Such notice
must be given at least two (2) hours prior to the time said officer is to
report for duty, if possible; otherwise said officer shall not be paid for the
sick day. All officers claiming pay for sick leave in excess of five (5)
consecutive days shall, before returning to work, submit a physician's
certificate stating the nature and extent of the illness or injury causing the
absence and also stating whether the physician is of the opinion that the
illness or injury is cured and the officer is able to return to work as a
police officer.
      6.   All officers shall be granted five (5) personal days off each year
with pay which can be used for illness, business, or any other lawful reason.
Personal days off shall be allowed to accumulate up to five (5) days per year,
not to exceed ten (10) days in any one year. No officer shall take a personal
day unless, however, such officer shall give two (2) days' notice to the Chief
of Police prior to using such day.
      7.   Officers served with notice that they are being sued shall
immediately notify in writing the Chief of Police and the Chairman of the
Police Committee of such suit. In addition, said officer shall deliver to the
Chief of Police copies of all documents served upon him.
   (D)   Vacation: Each full time police officer shall be entitled to a
vacation from duty with pay as set from time to time in accordance with the
annual vacation schedule of all employees adopted by the City Council. The
Chief of Police shall designate when such vacation shall be taken and may
schedule said vacations in such a manner to ensure that at all times adequate
personnel remain on and available for duty within the City of Momence. Any days
taken as vacation shall be taken in blocks of at least two (2) consecutive
days.
   (E)   Secondary Employment: No officer shall accept any other employment
unless and until the officer shall submit a request for permission to do so to
the Chief of Police. The Chief of Police shall have the final decision on
whether or not to grant the right to such officer to be employed in any other
occupation other than as a police officer. Any officer who engages in
employment outside of his regular duties as a police officer of the City of
Momence shall be subject to call at any time to perform the duties and fill the
responsibilities of a police officer of the City of Momence. In the event that
the Chief of Police determines that any secondary employment previously granted
permission for is conflicting with the ability of the officer to perform his
duties as a police officer of the City of Momence, he shall notify the officer
and the officer shall forthwith terminate such secondary employment. The Chief
of Police or the acting Chief of Police shall not, however, unless expressly
authorized by the Police Committee of the City of Momence, accept any other
employment while acting in the capacity as Chief of Police or acting Chief of
Police of the Momence Police Department. In the event that the Chief of Police
or acting Chief of Police desires to accept secondary employment, he shall
notify the Chairman of the Police Committee. Thereafter, the Chairman of the
Police Committee shall call a meeting as soon as is reasonably possible for the
purpose of discussing and deciding whether or not to authorize the Chief of
Police to so accept such secondary employment. In the event that the Police
Committee deems it acceptable for the Chief of Police to accept such secondary
employment, it shall so determine by a majority vote of those members present
at said meeting and may set certain restrictions and parameters on the nature
and extent of such secondary employment. In the event that the Police Committee
finds that said secondary employment would provide a conflict with said chief
of police's duties and responsibilities as chief of police, it shall so
determine. The decision of the police committee in this matter shall be final.
   (F)   Intergovernmental Cooperation: All officers shall cooperate with the
department and all other governmental agencies in the conduct of investigations
of criminal matters or instances involving police officers. Refusal to testify
before federal, state, county, or local courts, grand juries, investigative
committees, or the police committee of the city of Momence shall constitute
improper conduct and subject the officer to discipline.
   (G)   Property And Equipment:
      1.   Officers are responsible for the proper care of the department
property entrusted to them. Upon separation from the employ of the city of
Momence, all officers shall turn in and surrender to the chief of police all
department property in their possession.
      2.   All officers shall exercise diligence in their use of city property
and shall immediately report to the chief of police any loss or damage to any
department property or equipment assigned to them. All equipment shall be in
clean and good working order.
   (H)   Complaints Against Department Members: Any officer who receives a
complaint against another officer, known or unknown, from any source or agency,
whether written or oral, shall take such complaint in a courteous and efficient
manner. This complaint shall be forwarded in writing to the chief of police and
the chairman of the police committee. If the chief of police believes there is
a basis for further investigation, he shall so advise the chairman of the
police committee and the chairman shall then call a meeting of the police
committee to investigate and determine if there is any need for any further
action in regard to any of the allegations made in such complaint.
   (I)   Firearms:
      1.   Officers are considered to be on duty or eligible for duty at all
times and, therefore, shall be civilly armed but shall not be required to carry
a weapon while off duty if it would unreasonably impede the nature of their
activity. The chief of police is authorized to develop, promulgate, and form
rules and regulations regarding the equipment, uniforms, and weapons to be used
by all officers.
      2.   Whenever an officer discharges his firearm for whatever reason,
except in a firing range, he shall verbally notify the chief of police of such
discharge and the circumstances surrounding it and shall, within twenty four
(24) hours thereafter, make a full and complete written report of the incident
to the chief of police. A copy of such report shall also be sent to the
chairman of the police committee. Officers shall not possess their firearms in
any tavern or other place where alcoholic beverages are served except in the
line of duty.
   (J)   Communications And Correspondence: All officers shall read the
bulletin board daily when reporting to work for all orders and directions of
the chief of police. No other notices or documents may be posted on the
bulletin board without the prior consent of the chief of police.
   (K)   City Property: No officer shall use any city property for any private
or personal purpose.
   (L)   Public Activity: No officer shall appear as a representative of the
Momence police department at any public appearance, speech, or demonstration
without the prior permission of the chief of police. Officers shall at all
times be courteous and orderly in their dealings with the public. They shall
perform their duties in a professional manner avoiding harsh, violent, profane,
or insolent language and shall always remain calm regardless of the
provocation. Upon request of any citizen, officers shall supply their name and
number. They shall tend to requests of the public quickly and accurately
consistent with their obligations of the law and shall not criticize any other
officer or the chief of police in such a public fashion which would tend to
impair the operation of the department by impairing its efficiency and
interfering with the ability to maintain discipline. All officers shall make
maximum utilization of the grievance procedures as hereinafter set out to
resolve differences and disputes.
   (M)   Accidents: Accidents involving an officer and city property shall be
communicated in writing to the chief of police and the chairman of the police
committee as soon after such accident as is reasonably proper. Such report
shall describe the nature of the business of the officer at the time of the
activity, the names and addresses of all persons involved and all witnesses to
the accident, whether or not any person suffered injury and the nature of the
injury, and what the damage was to the vehicle involved.
   (N)   Department Use Of Motor Vehicles:
      1.   Officers shall not use any department vehicles for anything other
than official business while on duty and shall keep and maintain at all times a
valid driver's license necessary to operate said police vehicle. Each officer
