partition, wall, screen, curtain or other devices between such places of public
amusement and where said game or games are played and the public street or
alley nearest the same, that will obstruct, prevent or interfere with a full
view from such street or alley of the interior of such place of amusement where
said game or games are played. (Ord. 247, 1-2-1979)
3-4-7: HOURS:
All billiard and pool rooms and halls within the city shall be kept closed
between the hours of eleven thirty o'clock (11:30) P.M. Saturday to six o'clock
(6:00) A.M. of the day following, between the hours of eleven thirty o'clock
(11:30) P.M. Friday to six o'clock (6:00) A.M. of the day following, and
between the hours of ten thirty o'clock (10:30) P.M. Sunday to Thursday
inclusive and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. of the day following. (Ord. 255, 7-16-
1979)
3-4-8: REVOCATION:
The mayor may revoke any license granted under the provisions of this chapter
on proof that any of the provisions herein contained have been frequently
violated by the owner or keeper of any bowling alley or billiard room, his
agent or servant. (Ord. 247, 1-2-1979)
CHAPTER 5
PEDDLERS/TRANSIENT MERCHANTS
SECTION:
3-5-1: Definition
3-5-2: Transient Merchants
3-5-3: License Required
3-5-4: License Or Badge Nontransferable
3-5-5: Application
3-5-6: License Fee
3-5-7: License; Issuance And Revocation Or Suspension
3-5-8: Prohibited Conduct
3-5-9: Revocation
3-5-10: Penalty
3-5-1: DEFINITION:
PEDDLER: Any person, firm, or corporation who, for itself, or by its agents,
employees, or servants, by going from place to place within the city, sells at
retail, offers for sale, sells and delivers, barters or exchanges any goods,
wares, merchandise, or any other article or thing whatsoever, or any service
not ordered by telephone, computer link, or other remote communication. (Ord.
713, 7-5-2011)
3-5-2: TRANSIENT MERCHANTS:
The requirements of this chapter shall apply to any person, firm or corporation
who may open a place of business for the sale within the city, temporarily and
not intending to establish a permanent place for such business, to sell at
retail, offer for sale, sell and deliver, barter or exchange any goods, wares,
merchandise, or any other article or thing whatsoever, or any service not
ordered by telephone, computer link, or other remote communication, and such
person shall be considered a peddler for purposes of this chapter. (Ord. 713,
7-5-2011)
3-5-3: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of peddler within
the city without having first obtained a license therefor. Any person engaged
in the business of peddler in the city shall maintain on his or her person at
all times the license issued to him or her under this chapter, unless they are
exempt under subsection
3-5-6(C) of this chapter. (Ord. 713, 7-5-2011)
3-5-4: LICENSE OR BADGE NONTRANSFERABLE:
No license or badge issued under the provisions of this chapter shall be used
or worn at any time by any person other than the one to whom it was issued.
(Ord. 713, 7-5-2011)
3-5-5: APPLICATION:
Applicants for permit and license under this chapter must file with the clerk a
sworn application in writing on a form to be furnished by the city collector,
which shall give the following information:
   (A)   Name of the applicant.
   (B)   Phone number.
   (C)   Address (legal and local).
   (D)   A brief description of the nature of the business, goods to be sold,
where the merchandise was obtained, how the merchandise will be delivered, and
in the case of products of farm or orchard, whether produced or grown by the
applicant.
   (E)   If employed, the name, phone number, and address of the employer,
together with the credentials establishing the exact relationship.
   (F)   List the most recent cities or villages where the applicant conducted
business.
   (G)   The length of time for which the right to do business is desired.
   (H)   If one or more vehicles are to be used, a description of the same,
together with license number or other means of identification.
   (I)   A statement that, if a license is granted, it will not be used, or
represented in any way as an endorsement by the city or any department or
official thereof.
   (J)   Provide a copy of a fingerprint based criminal history record of
conviction in the last ninety (90) days provided by the Illinois state police.
   (K)   At the time of filing the application, a fee of ten dollars ($10.00)
shall be paid to the clerk to cover the cost of investigation. (Ord. 713, 7-5-
2011)
3-5-6: LICENSE FEE:
   (A)   Fee: The fee for a peddler's license shall be as established from time
to time by the city council. The mayor, with approval of the city council, at
their next regularly scheduled meeting, shall have the right to waive or adjust
said fees of this chapter.
   (B)   Basis Of Fees: For the purpose of this chapter, any period of seven
(7) calendar days or less shall be considered one week; any period of more than
six (6) calendar months and not more than one calendar year shall be treated as
a year.
   (C)   Exceptions:
      1.   The mayor, with approval of the city council at their next regularly
scheduled meeting, shall have the right to waive or adjust said fees of this
chapter.
      2.   Any person selling fruit, vegetables, farm products, or merchandise,
at an organized farmers' market.
      3.   Any person selling goods, wares, or merchandise at an organized
charitable, religious, civic, local or any other not for profit organization
sponsored event.
      4.   Any local resident under the age of fifteen (15) conducting curbside
nonalcoholic refreshment sales during community festivals.
      5.   Any person selling goods, wares, or merchandise at an organized flea
market.
      6.   Any person conducting what is commonly known as a "garage sale" or
"yard sale" at such person's residence. (Ord. 713, 7-5-2011)
3-5-7: LICENSE; ISSUANCE AND REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION:
   (A)   After consideration of the application and all information and data
obtained relative thereto, the city clerk shall license the applicant as a
peddler or transient merchant, if he determines that the applicant has the
qualifications and meets the requirements of this chapter, and all other
applicable laws and ordinances; if not, the application shall be denied and the
applicant shall not engage in or carry out any business herein defined, in the
city of Momence.
   (B)   The application shall be denied if the applicant or any person who is
to participate in the solicitation or any person having management or
supervision of the applicant's business has been convicted of a felony, or a
misdemeanor which involves lack of moral character, honesty, or integrity, as
determined by the result of an investigation conducted by the chief of police
within ten (10) years prior to the date of the application; or if he or any
person who is to participate in the solicitation has at any time violated the
provision of this chapter or any other applicable laws or ordinances of the
city of Momence or any county or municipality for a period of ten (10) years
prior to the date of the application, or if a license or other such permit to
engage in or carry out such business defined herein has been revoked by the
city or any other governmental agency or body. This application shall also be
denied if the purpose of the business is otherwise unlawful.
   (C)   If the application for a license is approved, the city clerk shall
forthwith issue the applicant a license, provided the applicant complies with
the requirements of section
3-5-3 of this chapter and pays the application fee as determined in section
3-5-6 of this chapter.
   (D)   At all times engaging or carrying out such business as defined herein,
in the city of Momence, the applicant shall prominently display said license
and shall exhibit same whenever he is requested to do so by any police officer
or by any person who approaches the applicant for purposes of engaging in or
carrying on the business defined therein.
   (E)   Any license issued under this chapter may be suspended or revoked by
the city clerk if the clerk has reason to believe that the license holder's
organization, or other members of license holder's organization have violated
any provisions of this chapter or any other provision of any ordinance of the
city, or any section of this code, or any statute, rule, or regulation of any
other governmental agency.
   (F)   Upon receiving a complaint or other notification alleging that a
violation has occurred, the city clerk shall fix a date and time for a hearing
and shall notify license holder, or license holder's organization either
verbally or in writing of the charge. At the hearing, the city clerk shall hear
such evidence bearing upon the question as may be presented by the complainant
and the license holder. Based upon the evidence taken at such hearing, the
police chief shall make a determination as to whether or not the license shall
be suspended or revoked, and shall cause his decision to be carried out. (Ord.
713, 7-5-2011)
3-5-8: PROHIBITED CONDUCT:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any peddler to cheat or deceive any person in
the city, or to fraudulently misrepresent the quality, price or amount of the
goods, wares, merchandise, article or thing, or service sold, offered for sale,
sold and delivered, bartered or exchanged.
   (B)   Any peddler, upon arriving upon any private property on which has
conspicuously posted a sign, "No Peddlers", or substantially similar sign,
shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises without attempting to
contact anyone, and it shall be unlawful for such peddler to remain on the
property.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful, and constitute a trespass, for any person to go
upon any premises and ring the doorbell, or create any sound in any other
manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of the residence,
for the purpose of securing an audience with the occupant thereof, and engage
in peddling, in defiance of the notice exhibited at the residence, in
accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
   (D)   Any peddler who has entered onto any private property, whether invited
thereon or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart therefrom when
requested to do so by the occupant, and it shall be unlawful for such peddler
to remain on the property after such request.
   (E)   It shall be unlawful for any person engaged in peddling to use sales
or other tactics based on force, intimidation, or psychological pressure; to
knowingly misrepresent himself or herself or their product to any city officer,
potential or actual customer, or to make or cause to be made, any contract,
order form, or instrument of indebtedness without full knowledge of the
customer.
   (F)   Any peddler shall at all times conduct himself or herself in
accordance with this code, local ordinances, state and federal laws and
regulations, and no peddler shall violate any such code, ordinances, laws or
regulations.
   (G)   No person shall engage in the business of peddler prior to nine
o'clock (9:00) A.M. and later than six o'clock (6:00) P.M. on any day, Monday
through Saturday. (Ord. 713, 7-5-2011)
   (H)   No person shall engage in the business of peddler prior to twelve
o'clock (12:00) noon, and later than five o'clock (5:00) P.M. on Sunday. (Ord.
784, 8-18-2014)
   (I)   Sale of products to any person standing on the roadway is prohibited.
(Ord. 713, 7-5-2011)
3-5-9: REVOCATION:
Any license issued under this chapter shall be revoked by the city clerk if the
holder of the license is convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of
this chapter, or has made a false material statement in the application, or
otherwise becomes disqualified for the issuance of a license.
   (A)   Immediately upon such revocation, written notice thereof shall be
given to the holder of the license, in person or by mail, at the address or
addresses listed on the holder's application. Any license previously issued
shall become null and void immediately upon personal delivery of such notice,
or three (3) days after such mailing.
   (B)   Any person whose license to engage in the business of peddler in the
city has been revoked may appeal such revocation to the city council of the
city by filing a written notice of such appeal with the city clerk. The city
council shall consider said appeal at its next regularly scheduled meeting
after the date of filing, and shall render a decision thereon as soon as
practicable. (Ord. 713, 7-5-2011)
3-5-10: PENALTY:
Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be subject to
penalty as provided in this code. Each day that any offense shall continue
shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 713, 7-5-2011)
CHAPTER 6
TAXICABS
SECTION:
3-6-1: License Required
3-6-2: Application
3-6-3: Fee
3-6-4: Compliance With State Law
3-6-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall operate for hire a taxicab within the corporate limits of the
city without having a valid license so to do, issued by the city as hereafter
set forth. (Ord. A-28, 6-16-1947)
3-6-2: APPLICATION:
An applicant for such a license shall file with the city clerk an application
under oath stating:
   (A)   His name and residence address.
   (B)   That he has complied with all the statutes of Illinois covering the
safe operation of taxicabs in this state. (Ord. A-28, 6-16-1947)
3-6-3: FEE:
The license fee shall be twenty five dollars ($25.00) per vehicle per annum,
beginning May 1 and ending on April 30, and the number of licenses issued in
the city shall be two (2). Such license fee shall be paid to the city treasurer
and upon the presentation of the treasurer's receipt to the city clerk, the
clerk shall issue said license which shall be signed by the mayor and the
clerk. (Ord. 210, 2-6-1978)
3-6-4: COMPLIANCE WITH STATE LAW:
Any violation of the laws of the state of Illinois relative to the operation of
taxicabs shall likewise be a violation of this chapter. (Ord. A-28, 6-16-1947)
CHAPTER 7
JUNKYARDS; DEALERS
SECTION:
3-7-1: Definitions
3-7-2: Vehicle License
3-7-3: Inspection
3-7-4: License To Store Or Collect Junk
3-7-5: License To Operate
3-7-6: Application For License
3-7-7: Issuance Of License
3-7-8: Other Premises
3-7-9: Penalty
3-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
JUNK: Old iron chain, brass, copper, tin, lead or other base metals, old rope,
old bags, wastepaper, paper clippings, wood scraps, rubber, rags, glass, empty
bottles of different kinds and sizes, when the number of each kind or size is
less than one gross, and all other articles and other things discarded or no
longer a manufactured item or used for their intended purpose, including, but
not limited to, abandoned automobiles, wood and any other such item.
JUNK DEALER: A person who engages in the business of buying and selling or
borrowing and exchanging junk, or who collects, receives, stores, holds in
possession for sale or exchange, or his own personal use any junk, whether
dealing in wholesale or at retail, or as a junk peddler.
JUNK PEDDLER: Any person who deals in junk, but does not occupy any premises
especially for such business. (Ord. 258, 6-2-1980)
3-7-2: VEHICLE LICENSE:
Every vehicle by any junk dealer or junk peddler shall display the name of the
licensee and his license number plainly on the exterior thereof or if a metal
license plate is issued by the city clerk, such metal plate shall be so
displayed. If metal badges are issued by the city clerk, a junk dealer, a junk
peddler and their employees shall wear such badge while engaging in the junk
business. (Ord. 258, 6-2-1980)
3-7-3: INSPECTION:
Every store yard or premises where junk is dealt in or stored shall be subject
to inspection by the police and fire departments. Inspections shall be made at
reasonable hours. (Ord. 258, 6-2-1980)
3-7-4: LICENSE TO STORE OR COLLECT JUNK:
No person not having been issued a license by the city clerk shall allow,
permit or suffer junk to collect or be stored on his premises. (Ord. 258, 6-2-
1980)
3-7-5: LICENSE TO OPERATE:
No person shall operate a junkyard or suffer or permit junk to be stored on his
premises or the premises so leased or occupied by him within the corporate
limits of the city without having a valid license to do so. (Ord. 258, 6-2-
1980)
3-7-6: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
An application for such a license shall be filed with the city clerk which
shall be signed under oath stating:
   (A)   His name and residence address;
   (B)   The location of the premises intended to be used for the storage or
collection of junk; and
   (C)   That such junkyard shall be surrounded by a solid fence of at least
seven feet (7') high. (Ord. 258, 6-2-1980)
3-7-7: ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
Upon the filing of an application as set forth and the payment of a license fee
of fifty dollars ($50.00) per year, the city clerk shall issue a license. (Ord.
258, 6-2-1980)
3-7-8: OTHER PREMISES:
No person shall make use of any property, private or public, not included
within the premises licensed under this section for the storage, handling, or
display of any junk. (Ord. 258, 6-2-1980)
3-7-9: PENALTY:
Any person found and adjudicated to have violated any provision of this chapter
shall be subject to the imposition of a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars
($500.00). Each day that any such person is found to have violated any
provision of this chapter shall be considered a separate offense. (Ord. 258, 6-
2-1980)
CHAPTER 8
MISCELLANEOUS BUSINESS REGULATIONS
SECTION:
3-8-1: Carnivals
3-8-2: Cigarette Sales
3-8-3: Garage And Yard Sales
3-8-4: Daycare Centers
3-8-1: CARNIVALS:
Any person desiring to run, conduct or show a carnival with tents, booths and
other structures on any of the streets, ways, lots or blocks within the city
limits shall first pay a license fee therefor of ten dollars ($10.00) and
provide the city council of the city with liability insurance, insuring the
city in a minimum amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00). (Ord. 210, 2-
6-1978)
3-8-2: CIGARETTE SALES:
No person shall sell, give away or attempt to sell or give away, either as
principal, clerk or servant, any cigarettes, cigarette papers or any cigarette
tobacco, including thereby any and all paper and mixtures used or to be used in
the making of cigarettes, without first obtaining a license therefor.
There shall be paid as a license fee under this section the sum of ten dollars
($10.00) per year, and all licenses issued under this section shall expire on
May 1 next after the date of issuance. Any person taking out a license under
this section at any time after the commencement of the then current year shall
pay into the city treasury, in advance, a sum at the rate of ten dollars
($10.00) per year for the remainder of the year; provided, that no license
shall be issued under this section for less than one-fourth (1/4) of a year.
(Ord. 210, 2-6-1978)
3-8-3: GARAGE AND YARD SALES:
Any person desiring to run, conduct or hold a garage or yard sale within the
city limits shall first pay a license fee therefor of five dollars ($5.00). No
more than four (4) licenses shall be issued to any household address for garage
and yard sales during any calendar year. A license shall not be issued nor
valid for a period exceeding three (3) consecutive days. (Ord. 396, 9-21-1992)
3-8-4: DAYCARE CENTERS:
   (A)   The definition of daycare center set forth in the child care act of
1969, 225 Illinois Compiled Statutes 10/1 et seq., is hereby adopted by and for
the city of Momence, Illinois, including any subsequent amendments to or
revisions thereof.
   (B)   The operator of any daycare center located within the city of Momence
shall annually register said daycare center with the city of Momence by
providing the following information:
      1.   The physical address where the center is located; and
      2.   The name and address of the operator of the daycare center.
   (C)   If the location of the daycare center is changed, the operator of the
daycare center shall notify the city of Momence of the new address within ten
(10) days thereof. (Ord. 587, 5-2-2005)
CHAPTER 9
MUNICIPAL OCCUPATION TAXES
SECTION:
3-9-1: Retailers' Occupation Tax
3-9-2: Service Occupation Tax
3-9-3: Municipal Use Tax
3-9-1: RETAILERS' OCCUPATION TAX:
A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of selling
tangible personal property at retail in the city at the rate of one percent
(1%) of the gross receipts from such sales made in the course of such business
while the provisions of this section are in effect, in accordance with the
provisions of 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-1.
Every such person engaged in such business in the city shall file on or before
the last day of each calendar month, the report to the state department of
revenue required by section three of "an act in relation to a tax upon persons
engaged in the business of selling tangible personal property to purchasers for
use or consumption" approved June 28, 1933, as amended.
At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the state department
of revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed on account of the receipts from
sales of tangible personal property during the preceding month. (Ord. 124, 9-
15-1969)
The exclusion contained in section 2(d) of the "retailers' occupation tax act"
approved June 28, 1933, as amended shall not apply to property within the city.
(Ord. 250, 1-2-1979; amd. Ord. 262, 9-15-1980; Ord. 264, 10-6-1980)
3-9-2: SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX:
A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the city in the business of
making sales of service at the rate of one percent (1%) of the cost price of
all tangible personal property transferred by said servicemen either in the
form of tangible personal property or in the form of real estate as an incident
to a sale of service, in accordance with the provisions of 65 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/8-11-5.
Every supplier or serviceman required to account for municipal service
occupation tax for the benefit of the municipality shall file, on or before the
last day of each calendar month, the report to the state department of revenue
required by section nine of the "service occupation tax act", approved July 10,
1961, as amended.
At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the state department
of revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed. (Ord. 125, 9-15-1969)
The exclusion contained in section 2(e) of the "service occupation tax act"
approved July 10, 1961, as amended shall not apply to property within the city.
(Ord. 250, 1-2-1979; amd. Ord. 262, 9-15-1980; Ord. 264, 10-6-1980)
3-9-3: MUNICIPAL USE TAX:
A tax is hereby imposed in accordance with the provisions of 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-6 upon the privilege of using in the municipality any
item of tangible personal property which is purchased outside Illinois at
retail from a retailer, and which is titled or registered with an agency of
Illinois government. The tax shall be at a rate of one percent (1%) of the
selling price of such tangible property with selling price to have the meaning
as defined in the use tax act, approved July 14, 1955.
Such tax shall be collected by the Illinois department of revenue for all
municipalities imposing the tax and shall be paid before the title or
certificate of registration for the personal property is issued. (Ord. 206, 1-
16-1978; amd. Ord. 262, 9-15-1980; Ord. 264, 10-6-1980)
CHAPTER 10
DOWNTOWN SIDEWALK DINING
SECTION:
3-10-1: Purpose
3-10-2: Permitted Areas
3-10-3: Alcoholic Liquor
3-10-4: Application/Permit
3-10-5: Permit Fee And Term
3-10-6: Regulations For Downtown Sidewalk Dining
3-10-1: PURPOSE:
The downtown sidewalk dining permit is intended to facilitate outdoor dining in
the downtown area; to create an active streetscape, enhance the economic and
social vitality of the downtown area; to promote pedestrian and retail
activity; to allow for the use of public sidewalks for such outdoor dining; to
expedite the approval of such facilities while ensuring that the public's use
of the sidewalks will not be significantly impaired by such dining; and to
prevent any adverse impact to adjacent properties from such dining. (Ord. 797,
7-20-2015)
3-10-2: PERMITTED AREAS:
Sidewalk dining shall be permitted only upon a property which is located within
the downtown district and zoned B-1. (Ord. 797, 7-20-2015)
3-10-3: ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR:
No alcoholic beverages shall be sold, served, consumed, or possessed by any
person within a sidewalk dining area unless the sidewalk dining area is
bordering the building face, and the premises has either a class A, B, or D
liquor license. (Ord. 797, 7-20-2015)
3-10-4: APPLICATION/PERMIT:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful to operate a sidewalk dining area, to engage in,
or allow sidewalk dining without first having obtained a sidewalk dining
permit.
   (B)   An applicant for a sidewalk dining permit shall file an application
with the city collector at city hall on such forms and subject to such
procedures as the mayor and city council may establish for such purpose. The
application shall be made to the city collector in writing, and signed by the
proposed applicant.
   (C)   The application shall state the name, address, and telephone number of
the applicant. It shall include a legal description and the address of the
premises proposed to be operated as a sidewalk dining area.
   (D)   The application shall include a plan with dimensions showing the
layout for the sidewalk dining area which accurately depicts the existing
sidewalk conditions, including sidewalk width from the building face to curb,
location and dimensions of any sidewalk features, or obstructions. The
application will include the design, location, size, and space of the sidewalk
dining area, chairs, tables, barriers, umbrellas, and other facilities to be
located within the sidewalk dining area. The application shall include proof of
insurance, detailed in subsection
3-10-6(N) of this chapter.
   (E)   No permit shall be issued to any applicant if the owner, or any
partner, shareholder, or resident manager, of said applicant is indebted to the
city, county, state of Illinois, United States Of America or any department
thereof.
   (F)   The liquor control commissioner, or his/her designee, shall review the
application to determine if the proposed sidewalk dining area meets the
requirements of this chapter. The liquor control commissioner, or his/her
designee, may approve, approve with conditions, or deny the application; upon
receipt of written approval, the city collector shall issue the sidewalk dining
permit. If the liquor control commissioner, or his/her designee, approves the
application, then the approved plan and permit shall be posted at the premises,
and be clearly visible to customers and the public. No material changes to an
approved plan may be made without prior written approval of the liquor control
commissioner, or his/her designee. No additional permit fee will be assessed
for such a change. (Ord. 797, 7-20-2015)
3-10-5: PERMIT FEE AND TERM:
The fee for a downtown sidewalk dining permit shall be twenty five dollars
($25.00) per year. The fee shall be nonrefundable and shall not be prorated. No
permit shall be assigned or transferred to any other person. The permit year
shall be May 1 through April 30. The permit shall state the name of the
applicant and specifically designate the sidewalk dining area. (Ord. 797, 7-20-
2015)
3-10-6: REGULATIONS FOR DOWNTOWN SIDEWALK DINING:
   (A)   Hours: The sidewalk dining area shall not be open to patrons except
during the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. to eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M.
daily. Applicant shall permit no use by any patron, member of the public or
other person within the sidewalk dining area, except during the permitted
hours.
   (B)   Sanitary Conditions: The sidewalk dining area must be kept sanitary,
neat, clean, and litter free at all times; the sidewalk dining area shall be
free from accumulation of food, litter, snow, ice, and other potentially
dangerous or unsanitary conditions.
   (C)   Food Preparation: No food preparation is permitted on the sidewalk
dining area; all food shall be prepared within the kitchen of the
establishment.
   (D)   Sound: See subsection
5-1-5(A) of this code.
   (E)   Storage Of Sidewalk Furniture: Furniture and other property used in
the sidewalk dining area by applicant shall not be stored in the public right
of way, and all such furniture and property must be removed from the sidewalk
dining area when the establishment is closed to the public for any period in
excess of seven (7) days.
   (F)   Smoking: The applicant shall not permit smoking within any sidewalk
dining area. "No smoking" signs shall be posted within the sidewalk dining
area.
   (G)   Space And Clearance: Sidewalk dining is permitted only on sidewalks
with a minimum width of ten feet (10') from the property line to the curb face;
the area designated for sidewalk dining shall be considered an extension of the
establishment; therefore the location of the sidewalk dining area must be
immediately adjacent to and have direct access to the establishment. In the
interest of public safety, sidewalk dining areas must maintain a clear
pedestrian path of at least three feet (3') at all times. This clear pedestrian
path must be free of any obstruction to allow pedestrian passage. Sidewalk
dining shall not interfere with any utilities or signs located on the sidewalk
and in the public right of way. Sidewalk dining shall not interfere with snow
removal within the clear pedestrian path; snow removal within the sidewalk
dining area shall be the responsibility of the applicant. Sidewalk dining areas
may not impinge on required clear distances for maneuvering around entrances or
exits. The sidewalk dining area must be accessible to disabled patrons and
employees. When a sidewalk dining area is located at a street corner, vision
clearance requirements shall be in accordance with city ordinances; and in all
events, the vision of pedestrians and of operators of motor vehicles shall not
be obstructed. These regulations shall also apply if a sidewalk dining area is
adjacent to an alley or driveway.
   (H)   Furniture And Other Elements: Tables, chairs, umbrellas, awning, and
any other elements associated with a sidewalk dining area must be of quality
design, workmanship, and materials to ensure the safety and convenience of
patrons as well as to enhance the visual and aesthetic character of the
streetscape and adjacent neighborhood. All sidewalk dining area elements will
be reviewed as part of the sidewalk dining permit process. Sidewalk dining area
chairs and tables must be placed only inside the area designated for sidewalk
dining. Table size should be kept to a minimum to avoid crowding. Appropriated
density of tables and chairs will be reviewed; and same shall be subject to
reasonable and appropriate conditions and restrictions. Permanent structures
are not permitted within sidewalk dining areas. Elements cannot be attached
permanently to sidewalks or other public rights of way. The applicant is
responsible for the restoration of the sidewalk or other public property if any
damage is caused by applicant's use of the sidewalk for sidewalk dining.
Temporary physical barricades to separate sidewalk dining areas from pedestrian
traffic are allowed if they are constructed of finished quality materials,
including wrought iron chains, rope stanchions, picket fencing, planters, etc.
Physical barriers clearly designating the sidewalk dining area (i.e., licensed
premises) is required if liquor is consumed at a sidewalk dining area. No signs
shall be placed on barricades.
   (I)   Overhead Structures: Umbrellas and other temporary overhead structures
are subject to approval during the sidewalk dining area permit process. No
portion of any umbrella shall be less than seven feet (7') above the sidewalk.
Umbrellas and overhead structures cannot interfere with street trees, must be
weather resistant, and designed to be secure during windy conditions. Awnings,
either permanent or temporary, are subject to approval during the sidewalk
dining area permit process. Awnings shall have no support posts located within
the public right of way, and no portion of an awning shall be less than eight
feet (8') above the sidewalk.
   (J)   Lighting: Lighting for sidewalk dining area is subject to approval
during the dining area permit process. Lighting must complement the existing
building and sidewalk dining area design and shall not cause a glare to passing
pedestrians or vehicles. Electrical wires are not permitted within the sidewalk
dining area. Acceptable tabletop lighting includes candles and low wattage
battery operated fixtures. Additional lighting may be attached to the adjacent
structure provided that written approval from the liquor control commissioner,
or his/her designee and all applicable city requirements are met.
   (K)   Outdoor Heaters, Fans, And Coolers: Outdoor heaters, fans, and coolers
for sidewalk dining areas are subject to approval during the sidewalk dining
area permit process.
   (L)   Vending Machines, Carts: Vending machines, carts, or other objects for
sale are prohibited.
   (M)   Service And Use: All services provided to sidewalk dining area patrons
as well as all patron activity (waiting, sitting, dining, etc.) must occur only
within the designated sidewalk dining area and not encroach on pedestrian
traffic area (i.e., the clear pedestrian path) at any time. Equipment necessary
for dispensing any other items is subject to review during the sidewalk dining
area permit process. The establishment must provide supervision of the sidewalk
dining area at all times.
   (N)   Insurance: Each applicant shall maintain the insurance coverage
required during the permit period. The insurance coverage shall be equal to or
better than, the requirement for any liquor license as set forth in subsection
3-2-6(D) of this title, and shall include all provisions designated in this
subsection. The insurance coverage is to be filed with the city collector, and
presented to the liquor control commissioner, or his/her designee, prior to the
issuance of a permit. Failure of the applicant to maintain any required
insurance shall subject the permit to suspension or revocation. The policy of
insurance shall provide for thirty (30) days' prior notice to the city if
coverage is substantially changed, canceled, or not renewed. The city shall be
named as an additional insured on a primary, noncontributory basis for any
liability arising directly or indirectly from the operation of a sidewalk
dining area. Each permit holder shall indemnify, defend, and hold the city
harmless from any loss that results directly or indirectly from the permit
issuance or operation of the sidewalk dining area.
   (O)   Liability: The use of the sidewalk dining area by applicant shall be
subject to, and conditioned upon the applicant maintaining liability insurance
as provided above. Permission to establish and maintain the sidewalk dining
area shall not be construed to relieve the establishment of liability for any
negligence on the establishment's part on account of, or in connection with the
sidewalk dining area. By acceptance of the authorization granted by the permit
to establish and maintain a sidewalk dining area and by establishing and
maintaining the sidewalk dining area, the applicant shall be deemed to have
promised and agreed to save harmless the city of Momence, Illinois, from any
and all liability (including attorney fees) and litigation fees arising by
reason of the formation, construction, placement, existence, use, or
maintenance of the sidewalk dining area.
   (P)   Immunity: The authorization granted by a permit approved under this
chapter to establish and maintain a sidewalk dining area is not intended to
constitute, and shall not be deemed to be a waiver of sovereign immunity by or
on behalf of the city of Momence, Illinois, or any of its officers or
employees.
   (Q)   Upkeep Of Sidewalk: Neither the city of Momence, Illinois, nor any
public utility company shall be responsible for damage to property of applicant
placed in the sidewalk dining area during repair, maintenance, or replacement
of the sidewalk, or during repair, maintenance, or replacement of a right of
way, or any public facility, or utilities in the area of the sidewalk dining
area. Applicant shall, upon reasonable verbal, or written notification from the
city of Momence, Illinois, remove any and all property of applicant designated
by the city of Momence, Illinois, whenever the city of Momence, Illinois,
desires to use the subject sidewalk for any purpose whatsoever. If applicant
shall fail or neglect to remove the property of applicant within the time
specified, the city of Momence, Illinois, shall have the right to remove the
property at the expense of the applicant and the city of Momence, Illinois,
shall not be liable to the applicant for any loss or damage to property of
applicant, including, but not limited to, any property within the sidewalk
dining area, caused by the removal.
   (R)   Revocation Of Permit: The permit issued herein may be immediately
suspended or revoked for cause, including violations of any provision of this
chapter. The permit herein may also be permanently revoked upon thirty (30)
days' prior notice to applicant if, and when, the city of Momence, Illinois,
requires use of its public right of way for any purpose inconsistent with the
present use of the right of way, and said sidewalk dining.
   (S)   Penalty: Any applicant or any person found guilty of violating any of
the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars
($100.00), nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each violation of
this chapter; and a separate offense shall be deemed to be committed on each
date in which a violation occurs or continues.
   (T)   Appeal: In addition to any penalty imposed for violation of this
chapter, the liquor control commissioner may suspend, or revoke any permit for
any violation of this chapter after affording the applicant due notice and
opportunity to be heard in its own defense. (Ord. 797, 7-20-2015)

CHAPTER 1

4-1-1: BUILDING CODES ADOPTED:
   (A)   Definitions: For the purpose of this chapter, and Building Codes, the
following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meaning
given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present
tense include the future; words in the plural include the singular; words in
the singular include the plural; and the word "shall" is mandatory while the
word "may" is permissive.
    OCCUPANT: Also known as lessee, renter, inhabitant, tenant, landlord,
owner, and/or responsible party for any premises in the City.
   (B)   Scope: The purpose of this section is to provide rules and regulations
for the construction, alteration, removal, demolition, equipment, use and
occupancy, location, repair and maintenance, of buildings and structures within
the City.
   (C)   Building Codes: The technical codes listed below are hereby adopted as
the Building Codes for the City of Momence and are incorporated herein as fully
as if set out at length. Three (3) copies are on file at Momence City Hall:
      1.   2012 International Building Code.
      2.   2012 International Residential Code.
      3.   2012 International Property Maintenance Code.
      4.   2012 International Fire Code unless there is a conflict with the
State's minimum edition requirement of the State Fire Code, or Life Safety Code
in which case, the State's minimum edition requirement of the State Fire Code,
or Life Safety Code, will supersede.
      5.   Most recent edition of the Illinois Plumbing Code. (Ord. 755, 1-7-
2013)
Violations of all adopted Building Codes can be enforced through issuance of
citation(s) by the Momence police or the Momence building inspector. The
minimum fine for each cited violation shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00).
The maximum fine shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00) each day that a
violation of an adopted Building Code exists. Each day shall constitute a
separate offense. (Ord. 848, 8-19-2019)

         (a)   The applicant for a permit for the removal of a building or

named insured in an amount not less than five hundred thousand dollars
($500,000.00) for personal injury or property damage, prior to the issuance of

forty eight (48) hours' prior notice. (Ord. 652, 10-20-2008)

through the issuance of citation(s) by the Momence police or the Momence
building inspector. The minimum fine will be doubled the required permit fee in
force from time to time. In the event that compliance is not met within seventy
two (72) hours of an issued citation, each day thereafter for which a required
building permit is not issued shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 848,
8-19-2019)
4-1-3: CERTIFICATE OF USE AND OCCUPANCY:
   (A)   Definitions: The certificate issued by the building inspector which
permits the use of a building in accordance with the approved plans and
specifications and which certifies compliance with the provisions of law for
the use and occupancy of the building in its several parts together with any
special stipulations or conditions of the building permit shall be called
certificate of use and occupancy.
   (B)   New Buildings: A building or structure hereafter erected shall not be
used or occupied in whole or in part until the certificate of use and occupancy
shall have been issued by the building inspector.
   (C)   Buildings Hereafter Altered: A building or structure hereafter
enlarged, extended or altered to change from one use group to another or to a
different use within the same use group, in whole or in part, and a building or
structure hereafter altered for which a certificate of use and occupancy has
not been heretofore issued, shall not be occupied or used until the certificate
shall have been issued by the building inspector, certifying that the work has
been completed in accordance with the provisions of the approved permit. Any
use or occupancy, which was not discontinued during the work of alteration,
shall be discontinued within thirty (30) days after the completion of the
alteration unless the required certificate is secured from the building
inspector.
   (D)   Changes In Use And Occupancy: After a change of use has been made in a
building or structure, the reestablishment of a prior use that would not have
been legal in a new building of the same type of construction is prohibited
unless the building complies with all applicable provisions of this Code. A
change from one prohibited use, for which a permit has been granted, to another
prohibited use shall be deemed a violation of this Code.
   (E)   Contents Of Certificate: When a building or structure is entitled
thereto, the building inspector shall issue a certificate of use and occupancy
within ten (10) days after written application. The certificate shall certify
compliance with the provisions of this Code and the purpose for which the
building or structure will be used in its several parts. The certificate of use
and occupancy shall specify the use group; the type of construction; and any
special stipulations and conditions of the building permit. (Ord. 403, 3-15-
1993)
4-1-4: REGISTRATION OF CONTRACTORS:
   (A)   All contractors, as that term is defined by ordinance in the County of
Kankakee, shall, prior to the commencement of any work in the City of Momence,
Illinois, submit to the City Collector, at the City Hall, of the City of
Momence, its license, duly issued, and in effect from the County of Kankakee.
The submission of such license, once a copy has been made, shall authorize the
contractor to perform work within the City of Momence, Illinois.
   (B)   Any contractor who violates any provision of this chapter shall be
subject to the general penalty as provided in subsection
1-4-1(A) of this Code. (Ord. 763, 7-15-2013)
CHAPTER 2
NUMBERING BUILDINGS 1
SECTION:
4-2-1: Title And Purpose
4-2-2: Numbering Plan
4-2-3: Assigning Of House Numbers
4-2-4: Fees
4-2-5: Numbers On Houses
4-2-6: Penalties
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  7-1-1, "Street Numbering", of this code.
4-2-1: TITLE AND PURPOSE:
This chapter shall be known, cited and referred to as HOUSE NUMBERING
ORDINANCE, for the following purposes:
   (A)   To set up a systematic numbering of all lots, buildings and structures
in the city;
   (B)   To provide for the orderly assignment of house numbers;
   (C)   To establish an agency for carrying out the provisions of this
chapter;
   (D)   To provide for the maintenance of proper records of house numbers
assigned and to provide records to be made available to any interested person.
(Ord., 4-1-1963)
4-2-2: NUMBERING PLAN:
House numbering required on lots, buildings or structures in the city shall be
numbered in accordance with the following plan:
   (A)   The dividing line for east and west numbers shall be the Dixie
Highway, also known as Range Street. The first block running east or west shall
be the 100 block, the second block the 200 block, etc.
   (B)   The dividing line for north and south numbers shall be Washington
Street. The first block running north or south shall be the 100 block, the
second block the 200 block, etc.
   (C)   Odd numbers shall be on the west and south sides of the streets; even
numbers shall be on the east and north sides of the streets.
   (D)   There shall be not more than one hundred (100) numbers to each block;
one number to every thirty feet (30') of frontage.
   (E)   Streets running diagonally or not generally north and south or east
and west shall be assigned numbers conforming as nearly as possible with the
blocks intersected.
   (F)   Lots, buildings and structures on streets not otherwise provided for
shall be assigned arbitrary numbers which shall be as consistent as possible
with the general plan.
   (G)   Two-family houses having multiple entrances on a street shall be
assigned separate numbers for each entrance.
   (H)   Two-family and multiple-family houses not having separate entrances
for each apartment shall be treated as apartment houses, and such building
shall be assigned one number, and individual families or apartments designated
as "Apartment 1", "Apartment 2", etc.
   (I)   Business and office buildings shall be assigned a number corresponding
to the main entrance of said building, with the separate and individual places
of business designated as "Room No. 1", "Room No. 2", etc. (Ord., 4-1-1963)
4-2-3: ASSIGNING OF HOUSE NUMBERS:
It shall be the duty of the building inspector of the city to assign house
numbers under the provisions of this chapter. Such house numbers shall be
designated on any building permit issued by said building inspector in addition
to the legal description of the property.
The building inspector shall cooperate with any individual requesting the
numbering of lots, buildings and structures in subdivisions or elsewhere within
and adjacent to the City limits.
The building inspector shall keep a record showing the proper street number
assigned to any lot, building or structure designated under the provisions of
this chapter, and such record shall be open to inspection by anyone interested.
Appeal from the decision of the building inspector may be taken to the Zoning
Board of Appeals 1  of the City by any interested person. It shall not be
necessary for said Zoning Board of Appeals to publish any form of notice in
connection with hearings held pursuant to the provisions of this chapter.
In the absence of or inability to act by the building inspector, the alternate
building inspector shall perform the duties required by this chapter, and the
Zoning Board of Appeals may assume the duties provided under this chapter to
the exclusion of the building inspector or alternate building inspector should
they deem it necessary.
Numbers designated under the provisions of this chapter shall be changed only
by action of the building inspector, the Zoning Board of Appeals or the City
Council. (Ord., 4-1-1963)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 2, chapter 5 of this Code.
4-2-4: FEES:
There shall be no fee required for the assigning of a number under the
provisions of this chapter. (Ord., 4-1-1963)
4-2-5: NUMBERS ON HOUSES:
It shall be the duty of the owner or occupants of every house, building or
structure in the City to have placed thereon, in a place visible from the
street, figures at least two and one-half inches (21/2") high, showing the
number of such building or structure; and no owner or occupant shall use any
number other than the number officially assigned under the provisions of this
chapter. (Ord., 4-1-1963)
4-2-6: PENALTIES:
Any person failing to number any building or other structure occupied by him
after receiving written notice to do so from the City of Momence Code enforcer
and who shall continue in his failure to so number such building or structure
shall be fined fifty dollars ($50.00) for each week during which a failure to
so number continues.
Any person using a number for any building or structure other than the one
assigned as provided in this chapter, after receiving notice from the City of
Momence Code enforcer, shall be fined fifty dollars ($50.00) for each week
during which a failure to conform to the correct number continues. (Ord. 837,
11-20-2017)
CHAPTER 3
DANGEROUS BUILDINGS
SECTION:
4-3-1: Nuisance Declared
4-3-2: Report Dangerous Buildings
4-3-3: Failure To Remedy Nuisance, Council Action
4-3-4: Notice To Be Posted
4-3-5: Liability Of Owner
4-3-6: Action To Prevent Accident
4-3-7: Closure Of Premises, Revocation Of License
4-3-8: Unsanitary Premises, Human Habitation Prohibited
4-3-9: Repair By City
4-3-1: NUISANCE DECLARED:
Any building or part thereof or any structure of like nature in a condition
dangerous to the occupants, or those passing, or to any adjacent buildings, by
reason of bad conditions of walls, overloaded floors, defective heating
apparatus, violations from machinery, defective flues, confined or cramped
stairways, insufficient exits, narrow or dark passageways, or which is unsafe
or dangerous for the purpose for which it is used or intended to be used, or is
in danger of being set on fire from any defect in its construction or is
especially dangerous in case of fire by reason of its dilapidated condition or
defective construction, or from other causes, or which may be prejudicial to
the public health or the health of the inhabitants of the neighborhood, shall
be deemed and is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. (Ord. 205, 1-16-1978)
4-3-2: REPORT DANGEROUS BUILDINGS:
Whenever it shall come to the knowledge of the building commissioner, fire
chief, health officer or complaint shall be made to them or any of them in
writing by any two (2) reputable citizens that any building, walls or structure
within the city is in such dangerous condition as described in the preceding
section, said building commissioner, fire chief or health officer, as the case
may be, shall forthwith report the same to the city council. (Ord. 205, 1-16-
1978)
4-3-3: FAILURE TO REMEDY NUISANCE, COUNCIL ACTION:
If it shall appear to the city council after due investigation of such report
that such building, walls or structure is in such dangerous condition as
aforesaid and the owner or his agent, or the lessee or occupant thereof, if
within his power or duty so to do, shall fail within a reasonable time to be
fixed by the city council, and after notice thereof in writing served on such
owner or his agent, or upon such lessee or occupant, by such officer of the
city as the city council shall direct, specifying wherein such building is
unsafe, defective or unlawful, to make the same safe in such a way as the city
council may direct, said building, wall or structure shall, upon the order of
said city council, be torn down and removed by the building commissioner or
made safe as said city council may order. (Ord. 205, 1-16-1978)
4-3-4: NOTICE TO BE POSTED:
Every building which shall appear to the building commissioner, health officer
or fire chief to be especially dangerous in case of fire by reason of bad
conditions of walls, overloaded floors, defective construction, decay or other
causes, shall be held to be an unsafe building and the building commissioner or
health officer as the case may be, in addition to proceedings as provided in
this section shall also affix a notice of the dangerous character of the
building in a conspicuous place on the exterior wall thereof, and any person
removing, defacing or disturbing such notice so affixed shall be liable to the
penalties as provided in this code. (Ord. 205, 1-16-1978)
4-3-5: LIABILITY OF OWNER:
An itemized account of the expenses of tearing down and removing such structure
or of putting the same into safe condition shall be kept by the building
commissioner and shall be presented to the owner of said structure or his agent
or to such lessee or occupant for payment, and in case such owner, lessee or
occupant, as the case may be shall fail or refuse, upon demand, to pay the
same, then the same may be recovered from such owner, lessee or occupant in an
action of debt in the name of the city. (Ord. 205, 1-16-1978)
4-3-6: ACTION TO PREVENT ACCIDENT:
In case the building commissioner or health officer finds any building or part
of a building in such condition as to endanger life where said condition may be
averted by the immediate application of precautionary measures, said officers
or either of them shall have and exercise the power (without the preliminary
direction of the city council), to take such precautionary measures as in his
opinion may be necessary to render any building or part thereof safe; provided,
the owner, lessee, occupant or agent of said building refuses or neglects to
take such precautionary measure after being notified so to do by said officers
or any of them. The decision and order of the said officers or any of them, as
the case may be, shall be absolute and final. (Ord. 205, 1-16-1978)
4-3-7: CLOSURE OF PREMISES, REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
   (A)   The building commissioner, health officer or fire chief may order that
no person shall be permitted to enter, occupy or use a dangerous building or
any portion thereof until the same shall have been made safe; and may post such
order in a conspicuous place on the exterior wall of such building. No person
shall enter, occupy or use (except for the purpose of repairing and making
safe) any building or portion thereof after the posting of such notice until
such building or portion thereof shall have been made safe.
   (B)   If the building or portion thereof found dangerous shall be devoted to
any purpose requiring a license, the mayor may suspend the license pending the
period of making repairs, and he may revoke the license in case of failure on
the part of the owner or party having an interest in such unsafe building or
portion thereof to make such without delay and at his expense. (Ord. 205, 1-16-
1978)
4-3-8: UNSANITARY PREMISES, HUMAN HABITATION PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful to occupy for human habitation any building which is
declared by the health officer to be unfit for such habitation by reason of
defective sanitary conditions until such conditions have been remedied and the
premises approved by said health officer as fit for occupancy. (Ord. 205, 1-16-
1978)
4-3-9: REPAIR BY CITY:
If work has been done and expense incurred by the city in connection with
dangerous buildings a bill of cost shall be rendered by the city to the owner,
lessee, occupant or agent of the property. The city may refuse to issue a
permit for the reconstruction, alteration or repair of any building or portion
thereof on the property involved until the expenditure incurred by the city on
account of the work and material supplied has been repaid. (Ord. 205, 1-16-
1978)
CHAPTER 4
SWIMMING POOLS
SECTION:
4-4-1: Compliance Required
4-4-2: Definitions
4-4-3: Building Permit Required
4-4-4: Conform To Approved Plans
4-4-5: Pool Construction And Location
4-4-6: Authority To Inspect And Close
4-4-7: Effect Of Compliance
4-4-8: Penalty
4-4-1: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
Every swimming pool hereafter constructed, installed, altered, maintained,
removed or demolished within the City, shall comply with all applicable
provisions of this chapter. In the event that compliance is not met within
seventy two (72) hours of an issued citation, each day thereafter shall
constitute a separate offense. Existing private residential swimming pools may
be continued without change, provided the requirements of this chapter are
observed. (Ord. 720, 8-15-2011; amd. Ord. 848, 8-19-2019)
4-4-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and their
derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the
context, words used in the present tense include the future; words in the
plural include the singular; words in the singular include the plural; and the
word "shall" is mandatory while the word "may" is permissive.
BUILDING INSPECTOR: The building inspector of the City of Momence or his
representative, duly appointed by the Mayor.
LOT: A portion of a subdivision or other parcel of land with or without
building development.
PERMANENT POOL: Any constructed pool that cannot be disassembled, moved or
relocated in its entirety or in parts.
PERSON: Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or
organization of any kind.
POOL DEPTH: The distance between the floor of the pool and the maximum
operating level of water when such pool is in use.
PRIVATE RESIDENTIAL SWIMMING POOL: A swimming pool, whether permanent or
temporary, which is intended for and maintained by an individual primarily for
the sole use of his household and guest and not for the purpose of profit or in
connection with any business operated for profit.
SWIMMING POOL: An accessory structure, whether indoors or outdoors, which is a
receptacle for water, or an artificial pool of water having a depth at any
point of more than twenty four inches (24") or with a capacity of more than one
thousand (1,000) gallons, which is used or intended for the purpose of
immersion or partial immersion therein of human beings, and including all
appurtenant equipment constructed, installed and maintained in or above the
ground.
TEMPORARY POOL: Any manufactured pool designed, either in its entirety or by
sections, for seasonal assembly and dismantling. (Ord. 720, 8-15-2011)
4-4-3: BUILDING PERMIT REQUIRED:
   (A)   No person shall construct, erect or alter a swimming pool without
first having obtained a building permit, issued and signed by the building
inspector.
   (B)   Application for a permit shall be in writing on such form as shall be
made available by the City. Such application shall briefly describe the
proposed work or structure and shall contain such information, drawings, plans
and specifications as are prescribed herein. Application shall be made by the
owner or lessee or agent of either, or the architect, engineer or builder
employed in connection therewith. Such application shall contain the full names
and addresses of the applicant and of the owner or lessee or agent of either,
and, if the applicant is a corporate body, its responsible officers.
   (C)   Such building permit shall be deemed an initial permit only and shall
not apply to permanent or temporary private residential swimming pools if an
alteration or change is made to the pool for which the initial permit was
issued. (Ord. 720, 8-15-2011)
4-4-4: CONFORM TO APPROVED PLANS:
All private residential swimming pools, appurtenances, water supply and
drainage systems shall be constructed in conformity with approved plans. If
deviation from such plans is desired, a supplementary plan conforming to
provisions of this chapter shall be filed. All work shall stop until approval
of the supplementary plan has been granted by the building inspector. (Ord.
720, 8-15-2011)
4-4-5: POOL CONSTRUCTION AND LOCATION:
   (A)   At least one means of egress shall be provided from private pools.
   (B)   Outdoor temporary or permanent swimming pools shall be provided with a
barrier which shall comply with the following:
      1.   The top of the barrier shall be at least forty eight inches (48")
above finished ground level. Where the tip of the pool structure is above
finished ground level, such as an aboveground pool, the barrier shall be at
finished ground level, such as the pool structure, or shall be mounted on top
of the pool structure.
      2.   When an aboveground pool structure is used as a barrier or where the
barrier is mounted on top of the pool structure and the means of access is a
fixed or removable ladder or steps, the ladder or steps shall have a barrier
which blocks admittance, unless the removable ladder is pulled out of the pool
when not in use.
   (C)   No portion of any private swimming pool or appurtenant equipment
(including pumps, filters, and heaters), except the walkway, shall be located
at a distance not less than one foot (1') from any side or rear property line
and may not be placed in any front yard. No appurtenant equipment serving the
swimming pool shall be permitted in the side yard between dwellings. Corner
lots will be considered as having two (2) front yards.
   (D)   All electrical devices used in conjunction with or connected to all
pools must be grounded and protected by approved ground fault interrupt
circuits.
   (E)   An approved pool cover shall be installed during those periods when
use of the pool is discontinued. Unused pools on residential premises not
occupied or dwelt in for a period of thirty (30) days or more shall be
completely drained or equipped with an approved pool cover. Abandoned pools, as
determined by the police department, shall be removed or filled to the grade of
adjacent land.
   (F)   Temporary private residential swimming pools shall be engineered and
designed to withstand all anticipated forces to which it will be subjected.
Wood shall not be used at, above or below grade as an integral part of the
structure.
   (G)   No temporary or permanent private residential swimming pool shall be
used, kept, maintained or operated in the city if such use, keeping,
maintaining or operation shall be the occasion of any nuisance, danger to life
or detrimental to health.
   (H)   The owners of all swimming pools existing on the date of the
publication of this chapter shall, within thirty (30) days from the date
thereof, comply with the terms and provisions of this chapter, and such owners
shall thereafter be subject to the penalties of this chapter. (Ord. 720, 8-15-
2011)
4-4-6: AUTHORITY TO INSPECT AND CLOSE:
If the city finds that the operation of the pool does not meet applicable
requirements of this chapter, or that such violations endanger the city water
distribution system, the pool will be closed until such time as the
requirements of this chapter are met. It shall be a violation of this chapter
to deny access to the pool to the aforementioned authorities between the hours
of nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. and five o'clock (5:00) P.M. (Ord. 720, 8-15-2011)
4-4-7: EFFECT OF COMPLIANCE:
Compliance with the provisions of this chapter does not alter or limit the
common law or statutory liability of any person. (Ord. 720, 8-15-2011)
4-4-8: PENALTY:
Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be subject to
penalty as provided in this code and as established in the list of fines and
fees. (Ord. 720, 8-15-2011)
CHAPTER 5
DEVELOPMENT IN SPECIAL FLOOD HAZARD AREAS
SECTION:
4-5-1: Purpose
4-5-2: Definitions
4-5-3: Duties Of The Building Inspector
4-5-4: Base Flood Elevation
4-5-5: Development Permit
4-5-6: Preventing Increased Damages
4-5-7: Protecting Buildings
4-5-8: Other Development Requirements
4-5-9: Variances
4-5-10: Disclaimer Of Liability
4-5-11: Penalty
4-5-12: Abrogation And Greater Restrictions
4-5-13: Separability
4-5-1: PURPOSE:
This chapter is enacted pursuant to the police powers granted to this city by
the Illinois municipal code 1  in order to accomplish the following purposes:
   (A)   To prevent unwise developments from increasing flood or drainage
hazards to others;
   (B)   To protect new buildings and major improvements to buildings from
flood damage;
   (C)   To promote and protect the public health, safety, and general welfare
of the citizens from the hazards of flooding;
   (D)   To lessen the burden on the taxpayer from flood control, repairs to
facilities and utilities, and flood rescue and relief operations;
   (E)   To maintain property values and a stable tax base by minimizing the
potential for creating blighted areas; and
   (F)   To make federally subsidized flood insurance available. (Ord. 450, 11-
4-1996)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1, 5/11-30-2, 5/11-30-8 and 5/11-31-2.
4-5-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following definitions are adopted:
BASE FLOOD: The flood having a one percent (1%) probability of being equaled or
exceeded in any given year. The base flood is also known as the 100-year flood.
BASE FLOOD ELEVATION (BFE): The elevation in relation to mean sea level of the
crest of the base flood. The "base flood elevation" at any location is as
defined in section
4-5-4 of this chapter.
BUILDING: A structure that is principally aboveground and is enclosed by walls
and a roof, including manufactured homes and prefabricated buildings. The term
also includes recreational vehicles and travel trailers to be installed on a
site for more than one hundred eighty (180) days.
DEVELOPMENT: Any manmade change to real estate, including:
   (A)   Construction, reconstruction, or placement of a building, or any
addition to a building, exceeding seventy (70) square feet in floor area;
   (B)   Substantial improvement of an existing building;
   (C)   Installation of a manufactured home on a site, preparing a site for a
manufactured home, or installing a travel trailer on a site for more than one
hundred eighty (180) days;
   (D)   Installation of utilities, construction of roads, bridges, culverts or
similar projects;
   (E)   Construction or erection of levees, dams, walls, or fences;
   (F)   Drilling, mining, filling, dredging, grading, excavating, paving, or
other alterations of the ground surface;
   (G)   Storage of materials including the placement of gas and liquid storage
tanks; and
   (H)   Channel modifications or any other activity that might change the
direction, height, or velocity of flood or surface waters.
"Development" does not include maintenance of existing buildings and
facilities; resurfacing roads; or gardening, plowing, and similar practices
that do not involve a change in the ground surface elevation.
FEMA: Federal emergency management agency.
FLOOD: A general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation of
normally dry land areas from the overflow, the unusual and rapid accumulation,
or the runoff of surface waters from any source.
FLOOD FRINGE: That portion of the floodplain outside of the regulatory
floodway.
FLOOD INSURANCE RATE MAP: A map prepared by the federal emergency management
agency that depicts the floodplain or special flood hazard area (SFHA) within a
community. This map includes insurance rate zones and may or may not depict
floodways and show base flood elevations.
FLOOD PROTECTION ELEVATION OR FPE: The elevation of the base flood plus one
foot (1') of freeboard at any given location in the floodplain.
FLOODPLAIN: "Floodplain" and "special flood hazard area (SFHA)" are synonymous.
Those lands within the jurisdiction of the city that are subject to inundation
by the base flood. The floodplains of the city are generally identified as such
on the flood insurance rate map of the city prepared by the federal emergency
management agency and dated November 20, 1996. The floodplains of those parts
of unincorporated Kankakee County that are within the extraterritorial
jurisdiction of the city or that may be annexed into the city are generally
identified as such on the flood insurance rate map prepared for Kankakee County
by the federal emergency management agency and dated September 6, 1996.
FLOODPROOFING: Any combination of structural or nonstructural additions,
changes, or adjustments to structures which reduce or eliminate flood damage to
real estate, property and their contents.
FLOODPROOFING CERTIFICATE: A form published by the federal emergency management
agency that is used to certify that a building has been designed and
constructed to be structurally dry floodproofed to the flood protection
elevation.
FLOODWAY: That portion of the floodplain required to store and convey the base
flood. The floodway for the floodplains of Kankakee River shall be as
delineated on the flood boundary and floodway map prepared by FEMA and dated
September 6, 1996. The floodway for each of the remaining floodplains of the
city shall be according to the best data available from federal, state, or
other sources.
IDOT/DWR: Illinois department of transportation/division of water resources.
MANUFACTURED HOME: A structure transportable in one or more sections, that is
build on a permanent chassis and is designed to be used with or without a
permanent foundation when connected to required utilities.
NFIP: National flood insurance program.
SFHA: See definition of Floodplain.
SUBSTANTIAL IMPROVEMENT: Any repair, reconstruction, or improvement of a
structure, the cost of which equals or exceeds fifty percent (50%) of the
market value of the structure either: a) before the improvement or repair is
started, or b) if the structure has been damaged, and is being restored, before
the damage occurred.
"Substantial improvement" is considered to occur when the first alteration of
any wall, ceiling, floor, or other structural part of the building commences,
whether or not that alteration affects the external dimensions of the
structure. The term does not, however, include either: a) any improvement of a
structure to comply with existing state or local health, sanitary, or safety
code specifications which are solely necessary to assure safe living
conditions, or b) any alteration of a structure listed on the National Register
of Historic Places or the Illinois Register of Historic Places. (Ord. 450, 11-
4-1996)
4-5-3: DUTIES OF THE BUILDING INSPECTOR:
The building inspector shall be responsible for the general administration of
this chapter and ensure that all development activities within the floodplains
under the jurisdiction of the city meet the requirements of this chapter.
Specifically, the building inspector shall:
   (A)   Process development permits in accordance with section
4-5-5 of this chapter;
   (B)   Ensure that all development in a floodway (or a floodplain with no
delineated floodway) meets the damage prevention requirements of section
4-5-6 of this chapter;
   (C)   Ensure that the building protection requirements for all buildings
subject to section
4-5-7 of this chapter are met and maintain a record of the "as built" elevation
of the lowest floor (including basement) or floodproof certificate;
   (D)   Assure that all subdivisions and annexations meet the requirements of
section
4-5-8 of this chapter;
   (E)   If a variance is requested, ensure that the requirements of section
4-5-9 of this chapter are met and maintain documentation of any variances
granted;
   (F)   Inspect all development projects and take any and all actions outlined
in section
4-5-11 of this chapter as necessary to ensure compliance with this chapter;
   (G)   Assure that applicants are aware of and obtain any and all other
required local, state and federal permits;
   (H)   Provide information and assistance to citizens upon request about
permit procedures and floodplain construction techniques;
   (I)   Cooperate with state and federal floodplain management agencies to
coordinate base flood data and to improve the administration of this chapter;
and
   (J)   Maintain for public inspection base flood data, floodplain maps,
copies of state or federal permits and documentation of compliance for
development activities subject to this chapter. (Ord. 450, 11-4-1996)
4-5-4: BASE FLOOD ELEVATION:
The best available base flood elevation data are listed below. Whenever a party
disagrees with the best available data, the party may finance the detailed
engineering study needed to replace existing data with better data and submit
it to the federal emergency management agency for approval.
   (A)   The base flood elevation for the floodplains of Kankakee River shall
be as delineated on the 100-year flood profiles in the flood insurance study of
the city prepared by the federal emergency management agency and dated November
20, 1996.
   (B)   The base flood elevation for each floodplain delineated as an "AH
zone" or "AO zone" shall be that elevation (or depth) delineated on the flood
insurance rate map of the city.
   (C)   The base flood elevation for each of the remaining floodplains
delineated as an "A zone" on the flood insurance rate map of the city shall be
according to the best data available from federal, state or other sources.
Should no other data exist, an engineering study should be done to determine
base flood elevations.
   (D)   The base flood elevation for the floodplains of those parts of
unincorporated Kankakee County that are within the extraterritorial
jurisdiction of the city, or that may be annexed into the city, shall be as
delineated on the 100-year flood profiles in the flood insurance study of
Kankakee County prepared by the federal emergency management agency and dated
September 6, 1996. (Ord. 450, 11-4-1996)
4-5-5: DEVELOPMENT PERMIT:
No person, firm, corporation, or governmental body not exempted by state law
shall commence any development in the floodplain without first obtaining a
development permit from the building inspector. The building inspector shall
not issue a development permit if the proposed development does not meet the
requirements of this chapter.
   (A)   The application for a development permit shall be accompanied by:
      1.   Drawings of the site, drawn to scale showing property line
dimensions;
      2.   Existing grade elevations and all changes in grade resulting from
excavation or filling;
      3.   The location and dimensions of all buildings and additions to
buildings; and
      4.   The elevation of the lowest floor (including basement) of all
proposed buildings subject to the requirements of section
4-5-7 of this chapter.
   (B)   Upon receipt of an application for a development permit, the building
inspector shall compare the elevation of the site to the base flood elevation.
Any development located on land that can be shown by survey data to have been
higher than the base flood elevation as of the date of the site's first flood
insurance rate map identification is not in the floodplain and therefore not
subject to the requirements of this chapter. The building inspector shall
maintain documentation of the existing ground elevation at the development site
and certification that this ground elevation existed prior to the date of the
site's first flood insurance rate map identification. (Ord. 450, 11-4-1996)
4-5-6: PREVENTING INCREASED DAMAGES:
Within the floodway identified on the flood boundary and floodway map, and
within all other floodplains where a floodway has not been delineated, the
following standards shall apply:
   (A)   Except as provided in subsection (B) of this section, no development
shall be allowed which, acting in combination with existing and anticipated
development, will cause any increase in flood heights or velocities or threat
to public health and safety. The following specific development activities
shall be considered as meeting this requirement:
      1.   Barge fleeting facilities meeting the conditions of IDOT/DWR
statewide permit no. 3;
      2.   Aerial utility crossings meeting the conditions of IDOT/DWR
statewide permit no. 4;
      3.   Minor boat docks meeting the conditions of IDOT/DWR statewide permit
no. 5;
      4.   Minor nonobstructive activities meeting the conditions of IDOT/DWR
statewide permit no. 6;
      5.   Outfall structures and drainage ditch outlets meeting the conditions
of IDOT/DWR statewide permit no. 7;
      6.   Underground pipeline and utility crossings meeting the conditions of
IDOT/DWR statewide permit no. 8;
      7.   Bank stabilization projects meeting the conditions of IDOT/DWR
statewide permit no. 9;
      8.   Accessory structures and additions to existing residential buildings
meeting the conditions of IDOT/DWR statewide permit no. 10;
      9.   Minor maintenance dredging activities meeting the conditions of
IDOT/DWR statewide permit no. 11; and
      10.   Any development determined by IDOT/DWR to be located entirely in a
flood fringe area.
   (B)   Other development activities not listed in subsection (A) of this
section may be permitted only if:
      1.   A permit has been issued for the work by IDOT/DWR (or written
documentation is provided that an IDOT/DWR permit is not required); and
      2.   Sufficient data has been provided to FEMA when necessary to approve
a revision of the regulatory map and base flood elevation. (Ord. 450, 11-4-
1996)
4-5-7: PROTECTING BUILDINGS:
   (A)   In addition to the damage prevention requirements of section
4-5-6 of this chapter, all buildings to be located in the floodplain shall be
protected from flood damage below the flood protection elevation. This building
protection requirement applies to the following situations:
      1.   Construction or placement of a new building valued at more than one
thousand dollars ($1,000.00);
      2.   Substantial improvements made to an existing building;
      3.   Structural alterations made to an existing building that increase
the floor area by more than twenty percent (20%);
      4.   Installing a manufactured home on a new site or a new manufactured
home on an existing site (the building protection requirements do not apply to
returning a manufactured home to the same site it lawfully occupied before it
was removed to avoid flood damage); and
      5.   Installing a travel trailer on a site for more than one hundred
eighty (180) days.
   (B)   Residential or nonresidential buildings can meet the building
protection requirements by one of the following methods:
      1.   The building may be constructed on permanent landfill in accordance
with the following:
         (a)   The lowest floor (including basement) shall be at or above the
flood protection elevation;
         (b)   The fill shall be placed in layers no greater than one foot (1')
before compaction and should extend at least ten feet (10') beyond the
foundation before sloping below the flood protection elevation;
         (c)   The fill shall be protected against erosion and scour during
flooding by vegetative cover, riprap, or other structural measure;
         (d)   The fill shall be composed of rock or soil and not incorporate
debris or refuse materials; and
         (e)   The fill shall not adversely affect the flow of surface drainage
from or onto neighboring properties; or
      2.   The building may be elevated in accordance with the following:
         (a)   The building or improvements shall be elevated on stilts, piles,
walls, or other foundation that is permanently open to floodwaters;
         (b)   The lowest floor and all electrical, heating, ventilating,
plumbing, and air conditioning equipment and utility meters shall be located at
or above the flood protection elevation;
         (c)   If walls are used, all fully enclosed areas below the lowest
floor must be used solely for parking or building access and shall be designed
