7-4-16: Private Wells, Ground Water And Potable Water
7-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
The words mentioned herein and used in this chapter and in proceedings hereto
shall, unless the same be inconsistent with the context, be construed to mean
as follows:
COMMITTEE: The Committee on Waterworks of the City.
CONSUMER: Any person who, himself or by his employees or customers, uses the
City water furnished by the City to the premises used and occupied by him, in
whole or in part, for business purposes; or any person who, by himself or by
any member of his family or by his guests, uses the City water furnished by the
City to the premises used and occupied by himself and family, or by himself, if
living alone, in whole or in part for dwelling purposes.
ENGINEER: The person in the employ of the City as an "engineer", as described
in this chapter.
MONTH: Calendar month.
OWNER: The owner of the premises supplied with water by the City.
PREMISES: Where same refers to those used for business purposes, shall mean the
one building owned or occupied by the consumer, separated from other or
adjoining buildings by division walls or partitions, but this shall not be
construed to include the premises of a consumer using and occupying more than
one building for the conduct of one and the same business; and where same
refers to dwelling houses, shall mean the one place of residence and the
outbuildings belonging thereto. (Ord., 4-3-1939)
7-4-2: CONNECTION; METERS REQUIRED; REGULATIONS:
Within two (2) years of the adoption of the ordinance codified herein, the
owner of all houses, buildings or properties situated within the City, located
on streets in which there is located a public water main, or are located within
five hundred feet (500') of a public water main, shall be required to make
connection to the public water main in accordance with all provisions of this
Code applicable to the application and installation of a connection to the
public water main including required payments. (Ord. 832, 11-6-2017)
   (A)   Meters Required: Any person, except as hereinafter provided, using
water furnished by the City or making any connection with any service water
supply pipe of the City shall connect his service pipe with a meter of standard
pattern, to be approved by the City Collector or Committee on Waterworks, so
that all water consumed shall pass through such meter and be accurately
measured and the amount definitely ascertained. In addition thereto, all such
persons using water furnished by the City shall install a remote water meter
reader on the outside of the premises being furnished water so as to allow the
reading of the meter by the City without entering the premises. The owner of
the premises shall pay for said remote reader and the cost of installation of
such shall be paid for by the City. The location of the remote reader shall be
determined by the City. All remote water meter readers shall be of a type
approved by the City Engineer or the Committee on Waterworks. (Ord. 267, 2-16-
1981)
   (B)   Setting Meters, Stop Boxes: All meters hereafter to be placed in
connection with the City waterworks system shall be set under the direction of
the City Engineer, in some convenient place in the cellar or, if there be no
cellar, on the first floor of the building to be served, to be approved by the
City Engineer, or, if outside of the building, such meter shall be set in brick
or concrete pits, having walls eight inches (8") thick, not less than three
feet (3') wide by three and one-half feet (31/2') long by four and one-half
feet (41/2') deep brought to grade, and provided with an iron or concrete cover
not less than eighteen inches by twenty inches (18" x 20") in size, suitable
steps or ladder shall be put in place for convenience of inspection and reading
of meter when required. The location of meter pits outside of buildings shall,
as far as practicable, be between the sidewalk and curb lines. When not
practicable to so place the meter pit, its location shall be designated by the
city engineer. Provisions shall be made to keep the meter pit free from water.
In tapping city water mains, a stop box or cut off shall in every case be set
on the service pipe, the top of which shall be flush with the surface of the
ground, and at the outer edge of the street sidewalk of the premises being
served. Any person removing, destroying or covering over any such stop box
shall be subject to penalty, liable for the cost of restoration of the same.
   (C)   Installation Of Meters: All meters shall be installed by the owner,
under the direction and supervision of the city engineer or committee on
waterworks, at the expense of such owner.
   (D)   Approval: All meters, before being set or reset, must be tested and
approved by the city engineer or the committee on waterworks.
   (E)   Removal Of Meters: No meter shall be removed for any purpose from any
supply pipe by any person whatsoever, without obtaining a written permit from
the city collector or committee on waterworks so to do. And when any meter is
removed by such consent of the city collector or committee on waterworks it
must be replaced within ten (10) days, and before being replaced it must be
tested and approved by the city engineer or committee on waterworks at the
expense of the owner.
   (F)   Meters To Be Sealed: All meters which are now installed and which
shall hereafter be installed in the city shall be sealed by the city engineer
or committee on waterworks or their assistant, and no meter shall be broken, or
seal thereon broken, until after the city collector or committee on waterworks
shall have been notified and the reading of the meter shall have been taken by
the city collector or committee on waterworks, or their assistant.
   (G)   Testing: Whenever any owner or occupant of premises shall deem that
his meter is registering incorrectly he may request the city collector to test
the same. The city collector shall, upon request, cause the person designated
by the city council for testing meters to remove and test the same at the
expense of such owner or occupant, the amount of such expense to be included in
his next water bill. Any meter not exceeding two percent (2%) from actual
correctness is hereby declared to be a correctly registering meter.
   (H)   Back Pressure: If a meter is used in connection with a steam boiler or
under any conditions where it is exposed to a back pressure, the same must be
protected by a check valve, placed between the outlet of said meter and such
back pressure.
   (I)   Failure Of Meter: If a meter at any time fails to register, or does
not register correctly, the sum the property owner shall pay for water service
for that month shall be the same as paid the preceding month. No deductions
shall be made from any bill on account of leakage. (Ord., 4-3-1939)
   (J)   Repair Of Meters: All meters now in use and connected, and all meters
hereafter to be placed in use in connection with the city waterworks system are
hereby declared to be fixtures, and shall be set and kept in good repair at the
expense of the owner, and any meter found in need of repair shall be removed by
the superintendent and repaired by him at the expense of the owner of the
actual cost of repairs and labor. Whenever it may become necessary to repair
the service pipe between the city main and any meter on account of leakage or
for other cause, such repair shall be made under the supervision of the
superintendent who shall be notified of the same, and at the expense of the
owner of the actual cost of repairs and labor, and such pipe shall be replaced
with copper pipe, in accordance with the provisions of subsection
7-4-3(B) of this chapter. (Ord. 569, 3-7-2005)
7-4-3: SERVICE PIPES; STOPCOCKS:
   (A)   There shall be a stop and waste cock attached to every supply pipe at
the point where it enters the building inside the same so as to admit the water
being shut off. Where service pipes are intended to supply two (2) or more
premises or tenements, a separate service cock shall be used for each tenement
or premises. (Ord., 4-3-1939)
   (B)   All service pipes shall be laid not less than four feet (4') below the
established surface grade at all points of all streets, alleys and public
grounds of the city where a surface grade is now or shall hereafter be
established; and, at least four feet (4') below the surface of the ground at
all other points; and, no pipe shall be used except three-quarter inch (3/4")
copper pipe from the water mains to the property line; and, no pipe except
three-quarter inch (3/4") copper pipe shall be used from the said property line
to the outlet of such service pipe. (Ord. 566, 11-1-2004)
   (C)   Hydrants, plugs, stop boxes, service pipes, stopcocks and all
attachments and fixtures pertaining thereto shall be kept in good repair and
condition by the owner or occupant of the premises upon which they are
situated, at his own expense. And it is expressly provided that no claim shall
be made or allowed against the city or any of its officers or employees on
account of the breaking of said water apparatus or on account of the stoppage
of the supply of water by reason of accident to the pumping machinery or mains,
or for the necessary alteration or repair of the same. The city collector, city
engineer or the committee on waterworks or their agents shall have free access
at all reasonable hours upon the premises of the consumer for the purpose of
reading the meter; or he or they may remove a meter at any time for repair or
for testing its accuracy, and when any meter shall be found incorrect in
measurement and unfit for further use, such meter shall be replaced at once by
one that is approved by the city engineer, at the expense of the owner thereof.
   (D)   In putting down and repairing pipes, the streets, avenues, alleys and
sidewalks shall be opened in a manner which will occasion the least
inconvenience to the public and which will admit the uninterrupted passage of
water along the gutter of the street, avenue or alley. No excavation in any
street, avenue, alley or other public place shall be left open overnight except
by permission of the city engineer and every precaution shall be taken to
ensure safety. The street, avenue, alley or sidewalk shall be restored to as
good a condition as it was in previously to making the excavation and all dirt
and rubbish shall be immediately removed after the completion of the work,
under the direction of and to be approved by the city engineer 1 . (Ord., 4-3-
1939)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  7-1-3, "Excavations", of this title.
7-4-4: PLUMBING:
Any plumber or pipe fitter wishing to do business in connection with the city
waterworks shall, before entering into an agreement to do so, procure a state
license and shall be governed in all respects by the ordinances and regulations
which are or may be adopted by the city council. Such plumber shall also be
responsible for all damages the city may sustain at his hands, and the city
council may require any and all plumbers and pipe fitters to give bond in such
amount as may be fixed upon, to indemnify and save harmless the city from any
and all damages the city may sustain by reason of his failure to comply with
all rules and regulations of the city which now or may hereafter be
established. (Ord., 4-3-1939)
7-4-5: TAPPING; CONNECTING:
   (A)   Persons To Perform Work; Supervision: No person except a plumber,
regularly licensed by the state shall do any part of the work of tapping or
connecting with any water mains or water pipes in the city, or with the laying
of the service pipes from the city water mains or water pipes, or with the
connecting of said service pipes with the meter, hydrant, faucet or other
service outlet, and all such work shall be done under the supervision of the
city engineer, or such other person as shall be chosen so to do by the city
council.
   (B)   Installation: The expense of tapping and connecting with the water
mains and water pipes of the city, and the expense of the service pipe
including all appliances and fixtures used and work done in so doing, and in
connecting the same with the meter, including the digging and filling of the
trenches in which said service pipes are laid, or that is necessary to be dug
and filled in order to successfully tap such water mains and water pipes, and
all repairs or alterations of said service pipes, appliances or connections
shall be paid for by the person at whose application such connections are made,
or work performed; provided, that the said water meter shall be furnished by
the city at cost to the property owner, to be paid for when delivered.
   (C)   Connections: All connections shall be made of extra strong lead pipe
of the weight herein specified, from the tap to the stop box, unless the meter
shall be placed on a city water main, and the number of taps shall be according
to the specifications of this subsection. The lead pipe shall not be less than
the following weights for the respective sizes:
 3/4" pipe, per foot, 3 pounds 8 ounces
11/4" pipe, per foot, 6 pounds
11/2" pipe, per foot, 6 pounds
In no case shall any tap of over three-fourths inch (3/4") in size be made in
any water main; and, where there is a one and one-fourth inch (11/4") supply
pipe, there shall be used not less than two (2) 3/4-inch taps; and where there
is a one and one-half inch (11/2") supply pipe, there shall be used not less
than three (3) 3/4-inch taps; and where there is a two inch (2") supply pipe,
there shall be used not less than four (4) 3/4-inch taps, and in no case shall
these taps be less than eighteen inches (18") apart in said water main.
   (D)   Cross Connections With Private Water Supply, Not Permitted: No person
shall be permitted to use a cross connection between the city water supply and
a private water supply or allow one to exist for any purpose whatsoever. If a
private water supply is used on any premises where the city water supply is
available, such private water supply shall not be used unless the city water
supply is completely disconnected from such private water supply either by an
air space in a manner approved by the city engineer or committee on waterworks,
or by capping the city water supply service.
Where a private water supply is used on the same premises with the city water
supply, a check valve of a type approved by the city engineer or committee on
waterworks and paid for by the consumer, shall be installed in the city water
service.
   (E)   Records Of Taps: It shall be the duty of the city collector to keep a
correct record of all taps made on the water mains of the city in a book to be
provided for that purpose, showing the location of the tap, the description of
the premises, and the date making said tap, and it shall be his duty, before
issuing a permit to any person to connect with such tap, to ascertain the
amount due and collect the same.
   (F)   Supervision: All taps and connections shall be put in under the
direction and supervision of the city engineer, who shall see that all the
material is of a quality suitable for the purposes for which same is used.
   (G)   Separate Taps: Every consumer shall have and maintain a separate and
independent tap for connection with the city water main for each building or
premises for which water is furnished, and no person shall be permitted to
connect his service pipe with the service pipe of any other consumer; and no
such taps or connections, heretofore made, shall be repaired or extended, but
whenever the same shall become in need of repair or an extension shall be made,
such service pipe shall be connected directly with the city water main in
accordance with the provisions of this subsection. (Ord., 4-3-1939)
7-4-6: CITY TO MAINTAIN WATER LINES:
The city shall maintain existing water lines of residents of the city and shall
maintain water lines hereafter installed by residents of the city from the city
water main to the curb stop. (Ord., 10-2-1961)
7-4-7: BUILDERS USING WATER:
Whenever builders, brick masons, plasterers or contractors use the water of the
city in or about their work, the same shall be metered and be charged for at
the regular rate. (Ord., 4-3-1939)
7-4-8: ACCESS TO PREMISES:
All employees connected with the city waterworks, the city collector, the city
engineer, the committee on waterworks or any member thereof, shall have free
access at all reasonable hours to premises where water is furnished by the
city, to make necessary examinations and inspections. (Ord., 4-3-1939)
7-4-9: TAMPERING WITH FIXTURES, HYDRANTS:
No person shall make any alterations, tamper with, or change in any manner, any
meter, water distribution control valve, service pipe, cock, any attachment, or
fixture pertaining thereto, without the written permission of the mayor,
superintendent of water and sewer, or public works director. No person shall
open or in any manner tamper or interfere with any city hydrant without the
written permission of the mayor, superintendent of water and sewer, public
works director, or some officer of the fire department of the city of Momence.
Penalty for violations of this section shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00)
per incident to be paid to the city. (Ord. 688, 7-5-2010)
7-4-10: SPRINKLING RESTRICTED:
All hose being used for garden purposes, street or lawn sprinkling, washing of
motor vehicles, buggies, etc., cleaning and like purposes must be shut off
instantly upon any alarm of fire being given, and shall not be used again until
signal is given that such fire is out.
The mayor of the city shall have the right, whenever in his opinion the public
good requires it, by proclamation, to order that no water from the waterworks
system of the city shall be used for street and lawn sprinkling; provided, that
in such proclamation he shall state the days or hours of the day when the same
shall not be used for such purposes; and it shall be unlawful for any person to
use water from the city waterworks system for such purposes during any time
when the mayor shall by such proclamation have prohibited its use. (Ord., 4-3-
1939)
7-4-11: RIGHT TO SHUT OFF WATER:
   (A)   In case of fire, or an alarm of fire, or while making repairs, or
constructing new work, the city reserves the right to shut off the city water
for as long a time as may be necessary.
   (B)   Any person who shall violate any of the provisions or requirements of
this chapter, or shall fail, neglect or refuse to comply therewith, shall have
the water turned off from his premises. (Ord., 4-3-1939)
7-4-12: USING WATER WITHOUT PERMIT:
It shall be unlawful for any person to use water from any hydrant, stopcock or
other fixture without first having obtained a permit from the city collector,
or for any person, having discontinued or been shut off from the use of the
water from the city waterworks system, to again commence the use of such water
without first having obtained a permit for so doing from the city collector, or
for any person to turn on the supply of city water without the permission of
the city collector or the committee on waterworks, or to use water from the
city waterworks system without the knowledge or consent of the proper
authorities. (Ord., 4-3-1939)
7-4-13: CONNECTION BEFORE LOCAL IMPROVEMENT:
The owner of any lot, tract or parcel of land abutting upon any street or
avenue in the city shall, within thirty (30) days after receiving notice in
writing of the intention to initiate a local improvement of the said street or
avenue, make all connections with the city water main and the city sewer in
said street or avenue from said main or sewer, to the curb line in front of
said lot, tract or parcel of land so abutting on the street or avenue to be
improved. The notice of public hearing by the board of local improvements in
any paving improvement of the roadway of any street or avenue in the city
shall, in the absence of other written notice, be considered and deemed due
notice under the requirement and provisions of this section.
No owner of any lot, tract or parcel of land abutting upon the streets or
avenues of the city, nor any other person, shall be permitted to excavate or
remove the roadway of any street or avenue for the purpose of making any
connection or connections with any city water main or sewer after the
completion of pavement or other local improvement of the roadway of said street
or avenue in the city, unless he shall have first obtained the consent of the
council thereto by a resolution in writing, duly adopted by the council, and
shall also have filed in the office of the city collector a bond in the sum of
five hundred dollars ($500.00) with good and sufficient sureties, payable to
the city and conditioned to replace and repair the pavement or roadway of said
street or avenue, and to put the same in as good a condition as it was in
previously to the excavating and making of the connection or connections, and
to maintain, repair and keep the same in such condition for the period of one
year after the making of the connection or connections aforesaid. (Ord., 4-3-
1939)
7-4-14: LIABILITY FOR DAMAGE:
The city shall not be liable for any damage caused by a leak or break in any
service pipe, or for damage caused by a failure to repair the same promptly,
nor shall the city be liable for any damage caused by the repair or
installation of such pipe or resulting therefrom when such work is not done by
the city. (Ord., 4-3-1939)
7-4-15: SERVICE FEES AND RECONNECTION FEES:
   (A)   In the event that as a result of nonpayment of sewer or water bills or
through any other voluntary or involuntary action on the part of the landowner
or occupant of any premises served by water in the city such water service is
turned off, then before such service shall be reconnected the owner or occupant
requesting such reestablishment of service shall, at the time of such request,
pay to the city the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) as and for a
reconnection fee. (Ord. 565, 11-1-2004)
   (B)   In the event that any water meter becomes damaged and is rendered
inoperable more than one time in any twenty four (24) month period, upon such
second occasion within any such twenty four (24) month period such owner or
occupant requesting a new or repaired water meter shall pay to the city upon
such request the sum of twenty five dollars ($25.00) as and for a service fee
for installing and/or repairing such water meter. (Ord. 313, 7-15-1985)
7-4-16: PRIVATE WELLS, GROUNDWATER AND POTABLE WATER:
   (A)   Private Wells:
      1.   Unlawful To Drill: It shall be unlawful for any person to drill a
private well in the city. (Ord. 568, 3-7-2005)
      2.   Use Of Water: It shall be unlawful for any person to use water from
any private well for drinking or cooking purposes. (Ord. 459, 8-18-1997; amd.
Ord. 466, 2-2-1998)
   (B)   Use Of Groundwater As A Potable Water Supply:
      1.   Prohibited: The use or attempt to use as a potable water supply
groundwater from within the corporate limits of the city by the installation or
drilling of wells or by any other method is hereby prohibited, except at points
of withdrawal by the city.
      2.   Definitions:
    PERSON: Any individual, partnership, copartnership, firm, company, limited
liability company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust,
estate, political subdivision, or any other legal entity, or their legal
representatives, agents or assigns.
   POTABLE WATER: Any water used for human or domestic consumption, including,
but not limited to, water used for drinking, bathing, swimming, washing dishes,
or preparing foods.
      3.   Penalties: Any person violating the provisions of this subsection
(B) shall be subject to a fine of up to five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day
for each violation. (Ord. 466, 2-2-1998)
CHAPTER 5
COMBINED WATERWORKS AND SEWERAGE SYSTEM
SECTION:
7-5-1: Systems Combined
7-5-2: Department Created
7-5-3: Application For Service; Deposit
7-5-4: Metering Of Water For Apartment Houses
7-5-5: Fire District; Hydrant Fee (Rep. by Ord. 485, 4-3-2000)
7-5-6: Liability For Payment
7-5-7: Delinquencies
7-5-8: Discontinue Service
7-5-9: Collector To Render Bills
7-5-10: Revenues Kept Separate
7-5-11: Waterworks And Sewerage Fund
7-5-12: System Of Accounts
7-5-13: Provisions On File With County
7-5-14: Delinquent Sewer Bills; Disconnection
7-5-15: Diverting Water Prohibited
7-5-1: SYSTEMS COMBINED:
   (A)   It is hereby found, determined and declared necessary for the best
interests of the city that the existing waterworks system of the city and the
existing sanitary sewerage system of the city be combined into a single utility
to be known and designated as the combined waterworks and sewerage system of
the city.
   (B)   All property, real, personal and mixed, comprising the now existing
waterworks system and sanitary sewerage system of the city is hereby found,
determined and declared to constitute the properties of the combined waterworks
and sewerage system of the city.
   (C)   Upon the effective date hereof said existing waterworks system and
said sanitary sewerage system shall be owned and operated by the city as a
combined utility, known as the combined waterworks and sewerage system of the
city, and all improvements and extensions to said waterworks and sewerage
system, either or both, shall be considered as improvements and extensions to
said combined utility; and all the properties, assets, obligations and
liabilities of all kinds of said waterworks system and of said sanitary
sewerage system, existing, outstanding and accruing or to accrue shall be held,
used, confessed and acknowledged as the properties, assets, obligations and
liabilities of said combined utility. (Ord., 1-3-1961)
7-5-2: DEPARTMENT CREATED:
There is hereby established an executive department of the city to be known and
designated as the combined waterworks and sewerage department of the city, and
there shall be placed in charge of the general management and control thereof a
superintendent, who shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the
city council expressed by ordinance, it being hereby determined and declared
that the establishment of said department and the appointment of a
superintendent thereof is necessary and expedient for the best interests of the
city, said superintendent shall qualify for office in the same manner as any
elective official of the city and shall post such bond in such amount as may be
determined by the mayor. All necessary employees of said department shall
likewise be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the city council
expressed by ordinance. (Ord., 5-18-1961)
7-5-3: APPLICATION FOR SERVICE; DEPOSIT:
Upon the application of the owner or any authorized agent or tenant of the
owner, premises will be furnished through the connections already made, and
upon compliance with the rates, rules and regulations of the city, and after
approval of the application by the city endorsed thereon.
The application shall state the name of the owner of the premises, the
character and extent of the service desired, the description of the premises,
including the name of the street and house number, if any, and such other
information as may be reasonably required by the city.
At the time of making application for service, applicant must make payment to
the city of the sum of twenty five dollars ($25.00), the same to be held by the
city during the time said service is furnished to the applicant as a security
deposit guaranteeing payment of bills submitted by the city for such service
from time to time. Upon termination of service the said security deposit shall
be returned to applicant.
A new application must be made and approved by the city upon any change in
ownership in property, or in tenancy, as described in the application, and the
city shall have the right to discontinue the water and sewer service until such
new application is made and approved. (Ord. 145, 12-20-1971)
7-5-4: METERING OF WATER FOR APARTMENT HOUSES:
Apartment houses containing four (4) or more separate units or apartments may
install one water meter of sufficient size and capacity to service all of the
rental units in a single building. In the event that one meter is so installed,
the owner of said building shall receive two thousand (2,000) gallons of water
per month for each unit of said apartment building for the minimum water rate
charged under the existing water rate schedule 1  times the total number of
units. After said total minimum gallonage has been consumed, the rates charged
for gallonage in excess thereof shall be in accordance with the existing
charges by the city allocated to the next succeeding gallonage bracket above
the permitted minimum times the total number of units in said building. (Ord.,
6-6-1966)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  7-6-1 of this title.
7-5-5: FIRE DISTRICT; HYDRANT FEE:
(Rep. by Ord. 485, 4-3-2000)
7-5-6: LIABILITY FOR PAYMENT:
   (A)   The owner of the premises and the occupant thereof and the user of
either water or sewage service or both water and sewage service shall be
jointly and severally liable to pay for the services supplied to the premises
and the services furnished to the premises by the city only upon the condition
that the owner, occupant, and user of the service become and remain jointly and
severally liable therefor to the city for payment thereof. (Ord. 295, 7-5-1983)
   (B)   Bills shall be rendered by the city at the end of each month and shall
be payable within twenty (20) days after the date thereof. If payment is not
made in the full amount of the bill within said twenty (20) day period, then
interest shall be added on the unpaid amount at five percent (5%) per month
from and after the due date of said bill until paid. (Ord. 560, 9-7-2004)
   (C)   In the event the city is required to commence legal proceedings to
obtain the payment of a delinquent sewer and water charge, then the owner,
occupant, or user, as the case may be, as defendant(s) shall, as provided for
by statute, pay to the city the city's reasonable attorney fees incurred in the
collection of said delinquent bill. (Ord. 295, 7-5-1983)
7-5-7: DELINQUENCIES:
   (A)   In the event said rates or charges for water and sewerage service, or
either of them including any penalty then due are not paid within thirty (30)
days after the rendition of the bill for such service, such charges and
penalties shall be deemed and are hereby declared to be delinquent. A
delinquency notice identifying the delinquent charges and penalty shall be sent
to the customer and all owners of record. The delinquency notice shall provide
that failure to pay the delinquent charges and penalty within fifteen (15) days
of the date of the notice may result in a lien upon the property.
   (B)   Once a delinquency notice in compliance with subsection (A) of this
section has been sent to all owners of record, a lien in the amount of the
delinquent charges is created upon the premises served. Whenever any charges
remain unpaid for fifteen (15) days after a delinquency notice has been sent,
the city may file with the county recorder of deeds a notice of lien. This
notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting out a description of the
premises served sufficient for the identification thereof, the amount of money
due and the date when such amount became delinquent. The city shall send a copy
of the notice of lien to all owners of record of the premises. (Ord. 637, 8-20-
2007)
   (C)   At the first council meeting in May, and every three (3) months
thereafter, the city clerk shall report a full list of names of all water
takers that have not paid their water rentals up to date. The city clerk shall
publish a list of all water takers who are delinquent in the payment of their
water rents by May 31 of each year, and shall also publish a list of all water
takers who are delinquent by November 30 of each year. (Ord. 708, 3-21-2011)
7-5-8: DISCONTINUE SERVICE:
If all charges and penalties for water and sewerage service, or either of them
are not paid within fifty (50) days after the rendition of the bill for such
service, then such service can be discontinued without further notice and
cannot be reinstated until all bills and penalties due thereon are paid in
full, and current. A payment of one hundred dollars ($100.00) is due for
service reinstatement. Should same owner have all charges and penalties for
water and sewerage service, or either of them not paid within the fifty (50)
days recur, then the service reinstatement fee shall increase an additional one
hundred dollars ($100.00) per occurrence. (Ord. 811, 3-7-2016)
7-5-9: COLLECTOR TO RENDER BILLS:
It is hereby made the duty of the city collector to render bills for water and
sewerage service, or either of them, and all other charges in connection
therewith, and to collect all monies due thereon, and it is hereby made the
duty of all officials of the city to enforce payment of all unpaid bills and
penalties in the manner and form, time and procedure under the laws of the
state of Illinois thereunto enabling. (Ord., 5-18-1961)
7-5-10: REVENUES KEPT SEPARATE:
All revenues and monies derived from the operation of the combined waterworks
and sewerage system shall be held by the city collector separate and apart from
his private funds and separate and apart from all other funds of the city, and
all of said sums, without any deductions whatsoever, shall be delivered to the
city treasurer not more than ten (10) days after the receipt of the same, or at
such frequent intervals as may from time to time be directed by the city
council. (Ord., 5-18-1961)
7-5-11: WATERWORKS AND SEWERAGE FUND:
The city treasurer shall receive all such revenues from the combined waterworks
and sewerage system and all other funds and monies incident to the operation of
said system, as the same may be delivered to him and deposit the same in a
separate fund designated as the "waterworks and sewerage fund of the city of
Momence", and said treasurer shall administer said fund in every respect in the
manner provided by state law. (Ord., 5-18-1961)
7-5-12: SYSTEM OF ACCOUNTS:
The city treasurer shall establish a proper system of accounts and shall keep
proper books, records and accounts, in which complete and correct entries shall
be made of all transactions relative to the combined waterworks and sewerage
system, and at regular annual intervals the city council shall cause to be made
an audit by an independent auditing concern, of the books to show the receipts
and disbursements of the combined system. (Ord., 5-18-1961)
7-5-13: PROVISIONS ON FILE WITH COUNTY:
A copy of this chapter, properly certified by the city clerk, shall be filed in
the office of the recorder of deeds of Kankakee County, Illinois, and shall be
deemed notice to all owners of real estate of their liability for water and
sewerage service supplied to any occupant or user of such services on their
properties. (Ord., 5-18-1961)
7-5-14: DELINQUENT SEWER BILLS; DISCONNECTION:
   (A)   In the event that any user of the city sewer service suffers or
permits the charges rendered by the city to such user for sewer services to
remain unpaid for a period of more than six (6) months, the city shall take all
necessary steps to disconnect said service. Prior to said sewer service being
disconnected, the city shall give said user thirty (30) days' notice to bring
all unpaid charges current. Said notice shall be by registered mail or, if said
occupant is no longer at the premises or refuses the delivery of registered
mail, by posting a notice of intended disconnection at said place of proposed
disconnection. Upon the expiration of the thirty (30) day period, the city
shall then take such steps to disconnect the delinquent user from the sewer
system. (Ord. 334, 11-17-1986)
   (B)   In the event that after said disconnection the present user or any
subsequent owner or occupant of said disconnected account desires to connect to
the sewer system, such connection shall be made by the city upon payment of the
total amount of unpaid sewer charges and a five hundred dollar ($500.00) city
reconnection fee. (Ord. 507, 11-19-2001)
7-5-15: DIVERTING WATER PROHIBITED:
It is hereby declared to be unlawful for any persons or other entity receiving
water to permit, allow or cause the diversion of potable water from said place
of use to any other dwelling. Each and every day that diversion of water off
premises takes place shall be considered a separate offense. (Ord. 509, 11-19-
2001)
CHAPTER 6
WATER AND SEWER SERVICE RATES AND CHARGES

7-6-1: WATER SERVICE RATES AND CHARGES:
7-6-1-1: WATER CONNECTION FEE:
All persons desiring to connect or tap onto the water line of the city shall
pay to the city clerk the appropriate sum from the table at the end of this
section prior to any such connection and shall obtain the approval of the city
building inspector as to the location and method of tapping onto said water
line prior to any connection thereto. No tapping shall be approved until the
city has further established that the water so being supplied shall be metered
in an appropriate fashion to allow the city to establish on a monthly basis the
amount of water consumed at said premises. All materials and installation by a
licensed plumber are the responsibility of said person desiring to connect or
tap onto the city water line.
Water tap-in fee1:

   1.   For multi-family residences, water tap-in fees are computed at the rate

(Ord. 792, 2-16-2015)
7-6-1-2: DETERMINATION OF RATES AND CHARGES:
The charge for water service will be based upon the amount of water consumed on
each premises supplied with water service by the waterworks system of the city
as follows:
   (A)   For each establishment furnished water, the charge shall be a minimum
of thirty-one dollars and sixty cents ($31.60) per month with a further charge
of two dollars ($2.00) per thousand gallons used, or part thereof, per month on
all gallons used. There shall be added to each monthly bill, in addition to the
calculated amount specified above, the additional sum of seven dollars ($7.00)
per month.
   (B)   Notwithstanding any of the above provisions regarding minimum charges,
it is hereby established for any service connection servicing more than one
residential unit through any size connection a minimum monthly charge of
thirty-one dollars and sixty cents ($31.60) times the number of units so
furnished from said connection and a further charge of two dollars ($2.00) per
thousand gallons used, or part thereof, per month on all gallons used times the
number of units furnished. There shall be added to each monthly bill, in
addition to the calculated amount specified above, the additional sum of seven
dollars ($7.00) per month.
   (C)   Notwithstanding any of the above provisions regarding minimum charges,
any establishment furnished water through more than one service connection
shall pay only one minimum service charge per month and shall further pay for
water furnished a charge of two dollars ($2.00) per thousand gallons used, or
part thereof, per month on all water used per month. There shall be added to
each monthly bill, in addition to the calculated amount specified above, the
additional sum of seven dollars ($7.00) per month.
   (D)   In the event the annual rate review is not completed by May 1 of each
calendar year, the rate will nonetheless increase by three percent (3%) and
shall remain at that amount for the next twelve (12) months unless another fee
is established, and the section amended. (Ord. 603, 3-6-2006; amd. Ord. 804,
11-2-2015; Ord. 871, 3-7-2022)
7-6-2: SEWER SERVICE RATES AND CHARGES:
7-6-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meanings of terms used
in this section
7-6-2 shall be as follows:
DOMESTIC USER: Any private residence, commercial establishment or institution
which discharges normal domestic sewage to the publicly owned treatment works.
INDUSTRIAL USER: Any manufacturing or processing facility that discharges
industrial waste to a publicly owned treatment works.
INDUSTRIAL WASTES: The wastewater discharges resulting from industrial, trade,
or business processes as distinct from their employees' domestic waste or waste
from sanitary conveniences.
NORMAL DOMESTIC SEWAGE: Wastewaters from segregated domestic and/or sanitary
conveniences as distinct from wastes from industrial processes, when such
domestic wastes do not exceed a BOD strength of two hundred milligrams per
liter (200 mg/l), or a suspended solids in excess of two hundred fifty
milligrams per liter (250 mg/l).
OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE COSTS: Includes all costs, direct or indirect,
necessary to provide adequate wastewater collection, transport and treatment on
a continuing basis and produce discharges to receiving waters that conform with
all related federal, state and local requirements. These costs include
replacement.
REPLACEMENT COSTS: The expenditures for procuring and installing equipment,
accessories and appurtenances which are necessary to maintain the capacity and
performance for which treatment facilities were designed, during their service
life. This term includes replacement.
SANITARY SEWAGE: The waste from water closets, urinals, lavatories, sinks,
bathtubs, showers, household laundries, basement floor drains, garage floor
drains, bars, soda fountains, cuspidors, refrigerator drips, drinking
fountains, stable floor drains, and all other water carried wastes except
industrial wastes.
SERVICE LIFE: Refers to the useful life of real property and equipment and
shall, for the purposes of this chapter, equal fifty (50) years for real
property and fifteen (15) years for new equipment.
SURCHARGE: The assessment in addition to the basic user charge and debt service
charge which is levied on those persons whose wastes are greater in strength
than the concentration values established in section
7-6-2-4 of this chapter.
USER CHARGE: A charge levied on the users of a treatment works for the cost of
operation and maintenance of such works. (Ord. 179, 3-1-1976)
7-6-2-2: SEWER CONNECTION FEE:
All persons desiring to connect or tap onto the sewer system of the city shall
pay to the city clerk the appropriate sum from the table at the end of this
section prior to any such connection and shall obtain the approval of the city
building inspector as to the location and method of tapping onto said sewer
system prior to any connection thereto. All materials and installation by a
licensed plumber are the responsibility of said person desiring to connect or
tap onto the city sewer system.

Note:
   1.   For multi-family residences, sewer tap-in fees are computed at the rate
of full price for the first unit and 1/2 price for each additional unit.
(Ord. 792, 2-16-2015)
7-6-2-3: DETERMINATION OF RATES AND CHARGES:
For the use of and the service rendered by the sewage works, rates and charges
shall be collected from the owners of each and every lot, parcel of real estate
or building that is connected with the city's sewer system or otherwise
discharges sanitary sewage, industrial wastes, water or other liquids, either
directly or indirectly, into the sewer of the city, which rates and charges
shall be payable as hereinafter provided and shall be in an amount determinable
as follows:
   (A)   Except as herein otherwise provided, sewage rates and charges per
month for the sewage works shall consist of a uniform fixed rate which shall be
charged to all users, and a variable rate applicable to all users which shall
be based on the quantity of water used on or in the property or premises
subject to such rates and charges, as the same is measured by the water meter
there in use.
   (B)   The fixed rate charged to all domestic users shall be twenty-five
dollars and eighty-eight cents ($25.88) per month and the variable rate
additional charge for all domestic users shall be two dollars and forty-one
cents ($2.41) per one thousand (1,000) gallons of water usage, or part thereof,
per month. These rates shall constitute the domestic user charge rate.
   (C)   Those classified as industrial users, the total fixed industrial
charge of forty-four thousand dollars ($44,000.00) per month, will be allocated
amongst all the industrial users based on each individual industrial users'
monthly use per one thousand (1,000) gallons of water as calculated by the
Superintendent of the Sewer Department compared to the utilization of that same
standard quantity of water per month by all industrial users. The variable rate
additional charge for all industrial users shall be two dollars and forty-one
cents ($2.41) per one thousand (1,000) gallons of water usage, or part thereof,
per month. These rates shall constitute the industrial user charge rate.
   (D)   In the event a lot, parcel of real estate or building discharging
sanitary sewage, industrial wastes, water or other liquids into the city's
sewer system, either directly or indirectly, is not a user of water supplied by
the city's waterworks and the water used thereon or therein is not measured by
a meter, or is measured by a meter not acceptable to the city, then the amount
of water used shall be otherwise measured or determined by the city, in order
to ascertain the rates of charge, or the owner or other interested party, at
his expense, may install and maintain meters, weirs, volumetric measuring
devices or any adequate and approved method of measurement acceptable to the
city for the determination of the sewage discharge.
   (E)   In the event a lot, parcel of real estate or building discharging
sanitary sewage, industrial waste, water or other liquids into the city's sewer
system, either directly or indirectly, is a user of water supplied by the
city's waterworks, and in addition uses water from another source which is not
measured by a water meter, or is measured by a water meter not acceptable to
the city, then the amount of water used shall be otherwise measured or
determined by the city in order to ascertain the rates of charge, or the owner
or other interested party at his expense may install and maintain meters,
weirs, volumetric measuring devices or any adequate and approved method of
measurement acceptable to the city for the determination of sewage discharge.
   (F)   In the event a lot, parcel of real estate or building discharges
sanitary sewage, industrial waste, water or other liquids into the city's sewer
system, either directly or indirectly, and uses water in excess of ten thousand
(10,000) gallons per month, and it can be shown to the satisfaction of the city
that a portion of water as measured by the water meter or meters does not and
cannot enter the sanitary sewer system, then the owner or other interested
party shall install and maintain meters, weirs, volumetric measuring devices or
any adequate and approved method of measurement acceptable to the city for the
determination of sewage discharge.
   (G)   In the event two (2) or more residential lots, parcels of real estate
or buildings discharging sanitary sewage, water or other liquids into the
city's sewer system, either directly or indirectly, are users of water and the
quantity of water is measured by a single water meter, then in each such case,
for billing purposes, the quantity of water used shall be averaged for each
user and the minimum charge and the sewage rates and charges shall apply to
each of the number of residential lots, parcels of real estate or buildings
served through the single water meter.
   (H)   The sewer rates shall apply to any user of the sewer system without
regard to what point in the sewage treatment process sanitary sewage, treated
or untreated industrial wastes, water or other liquids are inserted into any
point in the city's sewer treatment or delivery process.
   (I)   In the event two (2) or more dwelling units such as trailers,
apartments or housekeeping rooms discharging sanitary sewage, water or other
liquids into the city's sewer system, either directly or indirectly, are users
of water and the quantity of water is measured by a single water meter, then in
such case, billing shall be for a single service in the manner set out in
section
7-6-1-2 of this chapter, except that the fixed charge shall be equal to the
number of dwelling units multiplied by the fixed rate specified in subsection
(B) of this section. In the case of trailer parks the number of dwelling units
shall be computed and interpreted as the total number of trailers located and
installed in said park plus any other dwelling units served through the meter.
A dwelling unit shall be interpreted as a room or rooms or any other space or
spaces in which cooking facilities are provided.
   (J)   Where a metered water supply is used for fire protection as well as
for other uses, the city may, in its discretion, make adjustments in the
minimum charge and in the user charge as may be equitable.
   (K)   For the service rendered to the city, the city shall be subject to the
same rates and charges hereinabove provided or to rates and charges established
in harmony therewith.
   (L)   There shall be an annual rate review and likely increase to be
effective May 1 of each calendar year. In the event the annual rate review is
not completed by May 1st of each calendar year, the rate will nonetheless
increase by three percent (3%) and shall remain in that amount for the next
twelve months unless another fee is established and this section amended.
(Ord., 3-2-1970; amd. Ord. 179, 3-1-1976; Ord. 517, 6-3-2002; Ord. 601-A, 3-20-
2006; Ord. 873, 3-21-2022)
7-6-2-4: BASIS OF CHARGES; DETERMINATION OF RATE SURCHARGE:
In order that the rates and charges may be justly and equitably adjusted to the
services rendered, the city shall base its charges not only on volume but also
on the strength and character of the sewage and waste which it is required to
dispose of. The city shall require the owner or other user to measure and
determine the strength and content of all sewage and waste discharged, either
directly or indirectly into the city's sewer system in such manner and by such
method as may be deemed practical in the light of the conditions and attending
circumstances of the case in order to determine the proper charge. The owner or
other user shall furnish a central sampling point available to the city at all
times.
Extra charges based on the strength of the sewage and liquid wastes shall be
made on the following basis: (Ord. 516, 6-3-2002)
   (A)   Rate Surcharge Based Upon Suspended Solids: There shall be an
additional charge of twenty four cents ($0.24) per one thousand (1,000) gallons
of flow for each one hundred milligrams (100 mg), or fraction thereof, of
suspended solids in excess of two hundred fifty milligrams per liter (250 mg/l)
of fluid.
   (B)   Rate Surcharge Based Upon BOD: There shall be an additional charge of
twenty four cents ($0.24) per one thousand (1,000) gallons of flow for each one
hundred milligrams (100 mg), or fraction thereof, of biochemical oxygen demand
in excess of two hundred milligrams per liter (200 mg/l) of fluid. The city
council is authorized to prohibit the dumping of wastes into the city's sewer
system which, in its discretion, is deemed harmful. (Ord. 707, 2-22-2011)
   (C)   FOG Surcharge: The FOG surcharge for fats, oils, and greases (FOG)
loadings from industrial users which are in excess of one hundred milligrams
per liter (100 mg/l) are hereby established. When this concentration is
exceeded, the surcharge will be sixty cents ($0.60) per pound.
   (D)   Slug Or Slug Load: When a "slug or slug load" as defined herein is
detected at any location in the sanitary sewers, and the source of same can be
confirmed, a charge shall be made and invoiced by the superintendent, as
follows:
      1.   Two hundred dollars ($200.00) per day for the discharge of any
wastewater having a pH equal to or greater than 4.5 and less than 5.0.
      2.   Five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day for the discharge of any
wastewater having a pH less than 4.5.
      3.   A user whose discharge flow exceeds fifty thousand (50,000) gallons
per day of the violations or as an average during the month of the violations
shall be charged twice the amounts described in subsections (D)1 and (D)2 of
this section.
      4.   Plus any extra expenses, losses, and/or damages occasioned by the
city of Momence by reason of such "slug or slug load" entering the sanitary
sewers or POTW. (Ord. 516, 6-3-2002)
7-6-2-5: STUDY OF REVENUE SYSTEM:
In order that the rates and charges for sewage services may remain fair and
equitable and be in proportion to the cost of providing services to the various
users, the city shall cause a study to be made within a reasonable period of
time following the first full calendar year of operation subsequent to the
completion of the improvement project. Such study shall include, but not be
limited to, an analysis of the costs associated with the treatment of excessive
strength effluents from industrial users, determination of users subject to the
industrial cost recovery charges 1 , volume and delivery flow rate
characteristics attributed to the various users or user classes, the financial
position of the sewage works and the adequacy of its revenue to provide
reasonable funds for operation and maintenance, replacements and capital
improvements to the waste treatment system. Therefore, on an annual basis,
within a reasonable period of time following the normal accounting period, the
city shall cause a similar study to be made for the purpose of reviewing the
fairness and equity of the rates and charges for sewage services on a
continuing basis. Said studies shall be conducted by officers and/or employees
of the city or by a firm of certified public accountants and/or a firm of
consulting engineers which firms shall have experience in such studies. (Ord.
179, 3-1-1976)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  7-6-3 of this chapter.
7-6-2-6: USE OF REVENUES RESTRICTED:
Separate accounting procedures shall be established for the collection, holding
and disbursement of revenues generated under this chapter. Revenues thus
generated are to be used solely for the operation, maintenance and replacement
of the treatment works. (Ord. 179, 3-1-1976)
7-6-2-7: BILLING SYSTEM; LIABILITY OF OWNER:
The rates and charges shall be prepared and billed by the city monthly as the
city may deem appropriate and as determined by the bylaws and regulations of
the city as herein provided for and shall be collected in the manner provided
by law and ordinance 1 . Said rates and charges will be billed to the tenant or
tenants occupying the property served unless otherwise requested in writing by
the owners, but such billing shall in nowise relieve the owner from liability
in the event payment is not made as herein required. The owners of the
properties served, which are occupied by tenants, shall have the right to
examine the collection records of the city for the purpose of determining
whether such rates and charges have been paid by such tenants; provided, that
such examination shall be made in the office in which said records are kept and
during the hours that such office is open for business. (Ord. 179, 3-1-1976)
 
Notes
  2. See sections
1 7-5-6 through
  7-5-9 of this title.
7-6-2-8: ENFORCEMENT:
The city shall make and enforce such bylaws and regulations as may be deemed
necessary for the safe, economic and efficient management of the city sewer and
connections to the sewer system, and for the regulation, collection, rebating
and refunding of rates and charges. (Ord. 179, 3-1-1976)
7-6-2-9: EFFECTIVE DATE OF RATES:
Except as otherwise provided, the rates and charges as herein set forth shall
become effective on the date that sanitary sewers of the sewer system are made
available for connection to any lot, parcel of real estate or building; but in
any event, said rates and charges shall become effective no later than May 1,
1976. (Ord. 179, 3-1-1976)
7-6-2-10: ANNUAL COST REVIEW:
The superintendent, not less than annually, shall prepare an estimate of
Momence sewer utility cost components for operation, maintenance, and
replacement. These estimated cost components shall be reviewed no less than
annually, and approved by the city council. (Ord. 707, 2-22-2011)
7-6-3: INDUSTRIAL COST RECOVERY SYSTEM:
7-6-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meanings of the terms
used in this section shall be as follows:
ACT: The federal water pollution control act and amendments of 1972, public law
92-500, adopted by the 92nd congress on October 18, 1972.
INDUSTRIAL COST RECOVERY: The recovery by the city from the industrial users of
the treatment works of the grant amount allocable to the treatment of wastes
from such users pursuant to section 204(b) of the act.
INDUSTRIAL COST RECOVERY PERIOD: That period during which the grant amount
allocated to the treatment of wastes from industrial users is recovered from
the industrial users of such works, which shall be a period of thirty (30)
years.
INDUSTRIAL USER: Any nongovernmental user of publicly owned treatment works
identified in the "Standard Industrial Classification Manual", 1972, office of
management and budget, United States government, as amended and supplemented,
under the following divisions: A, B, D, E and I.
A user in the divisions listed above may be excluded from this class if it is
determined that it will introduce primarily domestic wastes or wastes from
sanitary conveniences.
INDUSTRIAL WASTES: The wastewater discharges resulting from industrial, trade
or business processes as distinct from their employees' domestic waste or waste
from sanitary conveniences.
NONINDUSTRIAL USER: Any governmental or residential user of a publicly owned
treatment works which introduces primarily segregated domestic waste or wastes
from sanitary conveniences. The term also includes commercial, institutional
and other industrial users where it has been determined that the waste
contributed by these users is primarily segregated domestic wastes or waste
from sanitary conveniences.
PROJECT: Project no. C170865 which is defined as a separate and distinct
project for construction of the Momence municipal sewage works which was
sponsored by the U.S. environmental protection agency under the provisions of
public law 92-500. This project does not include past or future construction,
equipment or other services not included under the specific project number and
in the approved plans, specifications and change orders for the project.
RECOVERED AMOUNTS: The annual payments from industrial users for their shares
of the federal grant allocable to the cost of treating industrial wastes, which
is determined by dividing the total federal grant amount allocable to treatment
of industrial waste by the industrial cost recovery period.
RETAINED AMOUNTS: Fifty percent (50%) of the amounts recovered from industrial
users, together with interest earned thereon. (Ord. 181, 3-1-1976)
7-6-3-2: DETERMINATION OF USES SUBJECT TO INDUSTRIAL COST RECOVERY CHARGES:
The city shall determine which users are subject to paying the industrial cost
recovery charges, in the following manner:
   (A)   The city shall require appropriate employees of the sewage works to
review billing records and prepare a list of all potential industrial users, as
identified in each of the divisions listed in section
7-6-3-1 of this chapter.
   (B)   The list of all potential industrial users shall be analyzed on the
basis of data available at the sewage works billing office (i.e., type of
business, volume charges, excessive loading charges, estimated number of
employees, etc.) for the purpose of developing preliminary lists of probable
"industrial" and probable "nonindustrial" users.
   (C)   The city shall conduct an immediate survey of all probable
"industrial" users in order to substantiate the validity of classifying a
particular user as an "industrial" user. Each user initially classified as an
industrial user shall be notified as to his classification.
   (D)   After completing the survey of all probable "industrial" users, the
city shall review the list of probable "nonindustrial" users to determine if
the initial classification of any of these users should be reconsidered. Where
appropriate, individual users will be contacted in order to determine the
proper classification.
   (E)   After an industrial user has been notified of his classification, the
user may request reconsideration by furnishing data and measurements acceptable
to the city for the determination of sewage discharge. The city shall have the
right to measure and determine the strength and content of all sewage and waste
discharges, either directly or indirectly into the city's sanitary sewage
system, in such manner and by such method as it may deem practicable in the
light of the conditions and attending circumstances of each case in order to
determine the proper user classification.
   (F)   Within a reasonable period of time following completion of the sewage
works construction project, the city shall have completed the initial
classification of all industrial users. During the first calendar year of
operation, subsequent to completion of the construction project, and annually
thereafter, the city will review, classify and reclassify all users as either
industrial or nonindustrial users based upon measurements and data obtained by
the city or furnished by individual users. Normally, each user will retain his
classification until the next succeeding classification period. However, if
there is a substantial change in the strength, volume or delivery flow rate
characteristics introduced into the treatment works by an individual user, then
the classification of the user may be reviewed and established during the year
in the light of the conditions and attending circumstances of each case. (Ord.
181, 3-1-1976)
7-6-3-3: DETERMINATION OF INDUSTRIAL COST RECOVERY CHARGES:
   (A)   In the event that a user of the treatment works is classified as an
industrial user and is not excluded from this classification based on its
sewage characteristics, a separate charge shall be levied on the user in
addition to that established in section
7-6-2 of this chapter. (Ord. 181, 3-1-1976)
   (B)   The industrial cost recovery charges for the treatment of industrial
wastes at the treatment plant shall be based upon the volume of sewage flow
billed to industrial users, as determined in accordance with appropriate
provisions for determining billed flow included in section
7-6-2 of this chapter and the total strength and character of industrial wastes
which is introduced into the waste treatment system. The strength and character
of industrial wastes shall be measured at the industrial user's expense as
provided for in section
7-6-2 of this chapter and furnished to the city. The owner or industrial user
shall furnish a central sampling point available to the city at all times. In
the event that measurement of the strength and character of industrial wastes
are not provided to the city on a timely basis, the measurements of the
strength and character of industrial wastes shall be determined by the city on
the basis of a sample, authorized hereunder, to be taken by the city for the
purpose of appropriate billing. The industrial cost recovery rates for the
treatment of wastes shall be as follows:
 
Monthly flow                $0.12 per 1,000 gallons
Monthly total pounds of BOD 0.08 per pound
Monthly total pounds of SS  0.08 per pound
 
(Ord. 515, 6-3-2002)
   (C)   However, in the event an "industrial user" can and does show to the
satisfaction of the city that a portion of the total monthly billed sewage flow
is from sanitary conveniences, then the flows and pollutant loadings to which
the industrial cost recovery charge is applied, shall be determined on the
basis of net flow and pollutant loadings excluding sanitary conveniences.
   (D)   If there is a substantial change in the strength, volume or delivery
flow rate characteristics introduced into the treatment works by an industrial
user, such user's share shall be adjusted accordingly.
   (E)   If there is an expansion or upgrading of the treatment works, each
existing industrial user's share shall be adjusted accordingly.
   (F)   An industrial user's share shall include only that portion of the
grant assistance allocable to its use or to capacity firmly committed for its
use.
   (G)   An industrial user's share shall not include an interest component.
(Ord. 181, 3-1-1976)
7-6-3-4: MONTHLY BILLING SYSTEM:
The industrial cost recovery charges for the treatment services on or after the
effective date hereof shall be prepared and billed monthly. (Ord. 181, 3-1-
1976)
7-6-3-5: REVENUE SYSTEM:
The city shall account for all industrial cost recovery payments in the
following manner:
   (A)   All revenues derived from the industrial cost recovery rates and
charges shall be segregated and kept in a special fund, separate and apart from
all other funds of the city. The special fund shall be designated the "water
pollution control center industrial cost recovery fund" and payment of said
amount into said fund shall be deemed a reasonable expense of operation of the
sewage works for the purpose of computing net operating revenue.
   (B)   Within one hundred twenty (120) days following the end of the first
calendar year after completion of construction and improvements to the
treatment works, and annually thereafter, the city shall return fifty percent
(50%) of the amounts recovered through the industrial cost recovery charges,
together with any interest earned thereon, to the U.S. treasury. The remaining
fifty percent (50%) retained by the city shall be invested in authorized
obligations of the U.S. government or any agency thereof pending use of the
retained amount for reconstruction or expansion.
   (C)   Eighty percent (80%) of the funds retained by the city in the water
pollution control center industrial cost recovery fund or authorized
investments and the interest earned thereon, shall be expended only for the
purpose of eligible costs of the expansion and reconstruction of the treatment
works associated with the project and necessary to meet requirements of the
act. All such expansion or reconstruction programs must be approved in writing
by the regional administrator of the U.S. environmental protection agency prior
to commitment or expenditure of the retained funds. The remaining twenty
percent (20%) of the funds retained by the city may be utilized for any
authorized use established by the city. (Ord. 181, 3-1-1976)
7-6-3-6: REVIEW OF RECORDS:
Upon request from EPA, the city shall encourage each industrial user to permit
representatives of the U.S. environmental protection agency to review
appropriate industrial sewage records for the purpose of independently
verifying the flow and characteristics of industrial wastes which are
introduced into the treatment works. No waste introduced into the waste
treatment system shall interfere with the operation or performance of the
sewage treatment works. All users are subject to the requirements of
pretreatment standards established by federal and state law. (Ord. 181, 3-1-
1976)
